TEXT:
TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   - started on neo... stopped ; continued on dopamine 9mcg
   - not synchronous w vent when sedation turned off, so pt started on
   propofol
   - after paralytic/sedation turned off, pH trended downwards; gave 1amp
   bicarb
   - started rewarming 2:30pm; still at 34.4C by 4pm
   - at 3:30pm became bradycardic, atropine given, PEA then pulseless VT
   arrest; CPR for 2 min, given 1mg atropine, 1mg epinephrine, 100 of
   lidocaine
   - re-started on neo after code
   - 4:45pm taken to Cath lab for tandem heart.
   - patient returned to CCU on heparin, neo, lidocaine and dopamine.
   - transfused 1 unit PRBC at 9pm
   - pt had poor paO2 and paCO2 on tandem heart.  Catheter adjusted to try
   to decrease right to left shunting.
   - 4:30am, patient continued to be severely hypoxic.  Perfusion called
   to add an oxygenator to tandem heart.
   Allergies:
   No Known Drug Allergies
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Midazolam (Versed) - 1.5 mg/hour
   Insulin - Regular - 4 units/hour
   Heparin Sodium - 50 units/hour
   Dopamine - 15 mcg/Kg/min
   Phenylephrine - 1.3 mcg/Kg/min
   Fentanyl - 150 mcg/hour

   Mg++:1.8 mg/dL, PO4:5.1 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   76 y/o F with hypertension who presented to OSH with acute ST Segment
   Elevation MI in cardiogenic shock, requiring IABP pump placement and IV
   Dopamine, who is s/p VT/VF arrest x 2.
   .
   .
   # Cardiac Arrest:
   On Arctic Sun protocol since midnight last night, reached goal temp
   2:30am.  Cooling for 12 hours because patient was hypothermic naturally
   for about 6hrs on her own prior to protocol.  Amiodarone infusion has
   been stopped.
   -          Rewarm starting at 2:30pm
   -          Paralytics and sedatives can start to come off w temp 35F,
   per protocol
   -          Will consider switching to propofol to help with constant
   waking up of patient for neuro exams, pending hemodynamic status per
   Swan-Ganz catheter
   -          Will monitor Neuro exam, f/u Neuro Recs
   -          EEG today and monitor for seizure activity
   -          Will exchange RIJ for Cordis to place Swan-Ganz catheter to
   get better sense of hemodynamic status and pressures
   # s/p STEMI:
   Has Intra-aortic balloon pump, on Heparin gtt
   -          will stop Heparin gtt temporarily for procedures
   -          continue aspirin, statin
   -          holding plavix for possible CABG
   # Cardiogenic Shock:
   Presumably has cardiogenic shock s/p STEMI in setting of hypotension.
   n        Measure wedge pressure and hemodynamic status with Swan Ganz
   catheter
   n        -check mixed venous O2sat
   # Lactic Acidosis
   Improved with bicarb and increased ventilation.  Stopped Bicarb drip
   b/c acidosis was overcorrected.  Now just has respiratory alkalosis,
   which will need to be monitored and corrected with ABGs and decreasing
   ventilation.  Had received 80% of 3amps of bicarb overnight.
   - monitor respiratory alkalosis and decrease ventilation by monitoring
   ABGs.
   .  .
   #  HYPERGLYCEMIA:  No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] be on
   hydrocortisone w study protocol
   - Continue insulin gtt.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:

   PA Catheter - [**2142-1-1**] 02:04 PM
   Sheath - [**2142-1-1**] 07:30 PM

   DVT:  heparin gtt
   Stress ulcer: famotidine

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female who presented to the emergency department with acute ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) in cardiogenic shock, requiring intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) placement and IV dopamine. She has had two episodes of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.2°C (99°F)
* Heart rate: 121 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 79/60 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 33 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 77%
* Central venous pressure (CVP): 15 mmHg
* Pulmonary artery pressure (PAP): 50/31 mmHg
* Cardiac output (CO): 2.43 L/min
* Cardiac index (CI): 1.8 L/min/m2
* Systemic vascular resistance (SVR): 1,745 dynes*sec/cm5
* Mixed venous oxygen saturation: 43-60%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 7.0 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 12.1 g/dL
* Creatinine: 1.2-1.3 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 14.65-19.34 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 5.5 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.5 g/dL
* Calcium: 6.4 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 5.1 mg/dL

The patient's cardiac status is complicated by cardiogenic shock, VT/VF arrest, and hypothermia. She has been treated with IABP, IV dopamine, and amiodarone infusion, which has been stopped. She is currently being cooled using the Arctic Sun protocol and is being monitored for seizure activity with EEG.

The patient's respiratory status is complicated by hypoxia, which is being treated with oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation. She has been given 1 unit of packed red blood cells (PRBC) and has had a poor response to tandem heart catheterization.

The patient's medical history is significant for hypertension, and she has no known drug allergies. She is currently taking aspirin, statin, and heparin, and is being held for possible coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Continued hypoxia and respiratory failure
* Cardiogenic shock and cardiac arrest
* Lactic acidosis and metabolic acidosis
* Hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia
* Sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction syndrome
* Pulmonary edema and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Neurological sequelae, including seizures and stroke

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continuing cooling therapy and monitoring for seizure activity
* Adjusting ventilation and oxygen therapy to improve oxygenation
* Monitoring for and treating lactic acidosis and metabolic acidosis
* Continuing insulin therapy to manage hyperglycemia
* Monitoring for and treating cardiac arrhythmias
* Considering coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) for possible revascularization.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female who presented to the emergency department with acute ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) in cardiogenic shock, requiring intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) placement and intravenous dopamine. She had a history of hypertension and presented with severe left anterior descending (LAD) and left main stenosis.

The patient experienced a ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest and was successfully resuscitated. She was then taken to the cardiac catheterization laboratory for a tandem heart procedure, which was successful. However, she continued to experience hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely secondary to catheter migration from the tandem heart device.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating myocardial infarction, and elevated lactate levels, indicating lactic acidosis. Her blood sugar levels are also elevated, and she is being treated with insulin.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is likely secondary to her acute STEMI and may require continued treatment with the tandem heart device and ECMO.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient's VF arrest was likely secondary to severe acidosis, which has now been corrected with ECMO.
3. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure is likely secondary to catheter migration from the tandem heart device and may require further treatment with ECMO.
4. Neurologic status: The patient's neurologic status is unknown, and further evaluation with EEG is needed to determine the extent of her brain damage.
5. Lactic acidosis: The patient's lactic acidosis has resolved with ECMO, but further monitoring is needed to ensure that it does not recur.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia is likely secondary to her acute illness and may require further treatment with insulin and hydrocortisone.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Continued treatment with the tandem heart device and ECMO to unload the left ventricle and improve cardiac function.
2. Weaning of pressors as tolerated to reduce the risk of cardiovascular complications.
3. Treatment of hypoxemic respiratory failure with ECMO and further evaluation of catheter migration from the tandem heart device.
4. Further evaluation of the patient's neurologic status with EEG and other diagnostic tests to determine the extent of her brain damage.
5. Monitoring of the patient's lactic acidosis and hyperglycemia to ensure that they do not recur.
6. Further treatment with antibiotics to cover potential ventilator-associated pneumonia.
7. Further evaluation of the patient's cardiovascular status with echocardiogram and other diagnostic tests to determine the extent of her cardiac damage.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female who presented with acute ST Segment Elevation MI in cardiogenic shock, requiring IABP pump placement and IV dopamine. She has had two episodes of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and ventricular fibrillation (VF), and one episode of pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest, which was successfully resuscitated.

Current conditions:

* Cardiogenic shock: The patient is still in cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest and is being supported with a tandem heart device with ECMO.
* Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient has severe hypoxia, likely secondary to catheter migration from the tandem heart device, which is being treated with ECMO.
* Neurologic status: The patient's neurologic status is unclear due to sedation, and an EEG is pending.
* Lactic acidosis: The patient's lactic acidosis has resolved on ECMO.
* Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia is being managed with insulin.
* STEMI: The patient has severe LAD and left main stenosis, and further clarification of her neurologic status is needed before proceeding with CABG.

Potential medical complications:

* Ventricular arrhythmias: The patient has had multiple episodes of VT and VF, and may be at risk for further arrhythmias.
* Pulmonary edema: The patient has worsening pulmonary edema, which may worsen her respiratory status.
* Aspiration: The patient may have aspirated during PEA arrest and CPR, which could lead to pneumonia.
* Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to her prolonged ICU stay and invasive lines.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient is at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding due to her anticoagulation therapy and invasive lines.
* Neurologic deficits: The patient may have neurologic deficits due to her prolonged sedation and possible aspiration.
* Cardiac complications: The patient may experience further cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock, due to her underlying cardiac disease and the need for further invasive procedures.

Recommendations:

* Continue to unload the left ventricle with the tandem heart device and ECMO.
* Titrate the flow to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 70.
* Wean the pressors as tolerated.
* Continue heparin therapy to maintain an activated clotting time (ACT) of 200.
* Keep the central venous pressure (CVP) above 15 to maintain optimal flow from the tandem heart device.
* Monitor the patient's neurologic status closely and wean sedation as tolerated.
* Await EEG results and neurology recommendations.
* Continue to manage the patient's hyperglycemia with insulin.
* Consider covering potential ventilator-associated pneumonia with cefepime and vancomycin.
* Review the patient's goals of care with her family and address any concerns.

   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated. Yesterday became bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with cardiogenic shock and acute ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) after presenting with severe chest pain and cardiac catheterization showing 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She had a syncopal episode at home, became unresponsive, and required intubation and dopamine for hemodynamic support. She had a PEA arrest and required CPR, followed by the placement of a tandemheart and ECMO. The patient has been stabilized, but remains critically ill with severe regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction, mild to moderate aortic regurgitation, and mild mitral regurgitation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock may worsen if the tandemheart device is not functioning properly or if the patient's cardiac function does not improve.
2. Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if the ECMO is not functioning properly or if the patient develops ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if she continues to bleed or if her hemolysis is not managed properly.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen if she continues to bleed or if her platelet count does not improve.
5. Neurologic Status: The patient's neurologic status is uncertain due to her sedation, and further evaluation is needed to determine the extent of her neurologic damage.
6. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to her intubation, central lines, and ECMO.
7. VAP: The patient is at risk for VAP due to her intubation and respiratory failure.
8. Renal Failure: The patient is at risk for renal failure due to her cardiogenic shock and ECMO.
9. Hepatic Failure: The patient is at risk for hepatic failure due to her cardiogenic shock and ECMO.
10. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient is at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding due to her anemia and thrombocytopenia.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's cardiogenic shock, hypoxemic respiratory failure, and anemia require ongoing management with the tandemheart device, ECMO, and blood transfusions. The patient's thrombocytopenia requires ongoing monitoring and potential platelet transfusions. The patient's neurologic status requires further evaluation and management. The patient is at risk for infection, VAP, renal failure, hepatic failure, and gastrointestinal bleeding, and will require close monitoring and management.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with acute ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) in cardiogenic shock. She underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with placement of a tandemheart device and ECMO. She experienced multiple cardiac arrests, including ventricular fibrillation (VF) and pulseless electrical activity (PEA), and was resuscitated twice. She has severe regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction and mild to moderate aortic regurgitation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 17-18 mmHg, MAP 70 mmHg, HR 108 bpm, BP 100/65 mmHg
* Respiratory support: intubated, receiving ECMO, FiO2 40%, PEEP 7 cmH2O
* Neurological status: sedated, unable to assess neurological function
* Laboratory results: WBC 7.7 x 10^9/L, Hct 26.5%, Plt 91 x 10^9/L, Cr 1.3 mg/dL, TCO2 20 mmHg, Glucose 118 mg/dL
* Imaging: CXR shows improved pulmonary edema, TTE shows severe regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction, mild to moderate aortic regurgitation, and mild mitral regurgitation

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiac function is severely compromised, and she is at risk of further deterioration.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and she is at risk of further deterioration.
3. Neurological compromise: The patient's neurological status is unclear due to sedation, and she is at risk of further neurological decline.
4. Sepsis: The patient has a urinary tract infection and is at risk of developing sepsis.
5. VAP: The patient is at risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to her prolonged intubation.
6. Lactic acidosis: The patient has resolved lactic acidosis, but she is at risk of developing it again due to her underlying cardiogenic shock.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient has hyperglycemia, and she is at risk of developing further complications if not managed properly.
8. DVT: The patient is at risk of developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to her prolonged immobility.

Plan:

1. Continue to unload LV with tandem heart device with ECMO.
2. Titrate flow to MAP ~70.
3. Wean pressors as tolerated.
4. Continue heparin gtt for tandem heart maintenance with goal ACT ~200.
5. Keep CVP >15-20 to maintain optimum flow from tandem heart.
6. Cover potential ventilator-associated pneumonia with cefepime and vancomycin.
7. Diurese today with 80mg IV lasix.
8. Wean sedation to allow for more definitive neurological exam.
9. Await EEG results.
10. Appreciate neurology recommendations.
11. Continue insulin gtt.
12. Continue to actively involve the family to address goals of care. Once neuro status determined, will have goals of care meeting.

Chief Complaint: 76F with [**Hospital 11306**] [**Hospital 1605**] transferred from OSH for CABG eval
   after cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. The
   patient then syncopized at home, unresponsive for 20-30 seconds,
   vomited, severe chest pain. POBA LAD and LCx, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated. Yesterday became bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT
   arrest. Had CPR for 2 mintes given 1mg atropine, 1mg epinephrine, 100
   of lidocaine. Received a tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to
   partially in the RA causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated.
   24 Hour Events:
   - Repositioning of tandem heart catheter
   - Pending Neuro re-eval off sedation for 24hrs
   - 12am - pt noted to have dropped Hct to 24 (from 36 in AM). (Tandem
   Heart rep says hemolysis not likely from machine. Did not CT for
   possible RP bleed b/c could not intervene. Pt has had some blood
   suctioned from ETT.)
   - transfused 2u PRBCs ; Hct bumped appropriately but platelets
   dropping; low suspicion HIT, per HIT protocol
   - transfused 1u platelets w approp bump
   - patient w spontaneous movements, concern for discomfort, so started
   on low dose fentanyl ~10pm?, to which she responded well, to be turned
   off early AM [**2142-1-3**]
   - patient reached warming goal of 37C 4am and was maintained at temp w
   arctic sun machine
   - Hct 26.5, plts stable 91 in AM labs --> transfusing 1u pRBCs more;
   CVP 17-18

The patient is a 76-year-old female who was transferred to the ICU from the operating room (OSH) after undergoing cardiac catheterization and subsequent cardiac arrest. The patient's condition is complex and involves multiple medical complications.

The patient's primary diagnosis is cardiogenic shock, which was caused by a severe anterior myocardial infarction (STEMI) due to 95% left main coronary artery disease and 99% left anterior descending coronary artery stenosis. The patient's cardiac arrest was likely secondary to severe acidosis, which was corrected with the use of a tandem heart device and ECMO.

The patient's respiratory status is also compromised, with a diagnosis of hypoxemic respiratory failure. This is likely due to catheter migration from the tandem heart device, as well as acute congestive heart failure. The patient is currently being treated with ECMO and is showing signs of improvement.

The patient's neurological status is also a concern, with a diagnosis of possible aspiration during cardiac arrest and CPR. The patient is currently sedated and is awaiting further neurological evaluation.

Other medical complications include lactic acidosis, which has resolved with the use of ECMO, and hyperglycemia, which is being treated with insulin.

The patient's goals of care are to be actively involved in the decision-making process with her family, with the ultimate goal of determining the best course of treatment for her condition.

Potential medical complications that could arise include:

1. Cardiac arrest: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and cardiogenic shock puts her at risk for further cardiac arrests.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure could worsen, leading to further respiratory compromise.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's possible aspiration during cardiac arrest and CPR could lead to further neurological damage.
4. Infection: The patient's use of ECMO and her compromised immune system make her at risk for infection.
5. Hemorrhage: The patient's use of anticoagulation therapy and her compromised coagulation status make her at risk for hemorrhage.
6. Kidney failure: The patient's compromised renal function and her use of diuretics make her at risk for kidney failure.
7. Liver failure: The patient's compromised liver function and her use of medications make her at risk for liver failure.

In conclusion, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

   76F with [**Hospital 11306**] [**Hospital 1605**] transferred from OSH after syncope episode and chest
   pain, cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. POBA LAD
   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated. On [**1-2**] became bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT
   arrest. Had CPR for 2 mintes given 1mg atropine, 1mg epinephrine, 100
   of lidocaine. Received a tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to
   partially in the RA causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. [**1-3**] hematocrit
   and plt drop requiring transfusion.
   #Cardiogenic shock: Patient was in cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest.
   s/p tandemheart and ECMO. Patient's heart appears to be able to
   accomplish some of the workload. Will wean tandem heart as tolerated.
   Issue at this point is respiratory failure and need for ECMO for proper
   oxygenation.
   - Continue tandemheart device with ECMO - once respiratory status
   improves wean
   - Titrate flow to MAP above 70
   - Wean dopamine as tolerated
   - Continue heparin gtt for tandemheart maintenance with goal ACT - 200
   - Consider transfusion if HD unstable
   - appreciate cardiac surgery recommendations
   - TTE today
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure: New respiratory failure likely
   secondary to catheter migration from tandem heart device. Other
   respiratory failure may be secondary to acute congestive heart failure
   vs hemorrhage vs aspiration pneumonitis vs ARDS vs other. Respiratory
   status is a major factor in surgery decision. Will attempt to maxamize
   status over next couple of days.
   - treated with ECMO
   - CXR with worsened bilateral edema
   - ARDS net vent settings
   - Cover potential ventilator associated pneumonia with cefepime and
   vancomycin (day [**2-5**]), plan for 8 day course for VAP
   - Lasix gtt
   - CT torso
   - consider pulmonary consult if CXR/respiratory status not improved
   with diuresis
   # Anemia: Unclear etiology. Required 3u pRBCs yesterday. The patient
   had significant OP bleed. ENT evaluated and packed nasal and oral
   cavities. They will follow. Unlikely to explain total hct drop. Pt also
   has evidence of hemolysis, likely from external lines. RP bleed or GI
   bleed a possibility although no clear evidence for those as of yet.
   - trend, transfuse if rapidly dropping hct, signs of hypoperfusion
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Unclear etiology. Required 1u plts yesterday.
   Remained relatively stable over the course of the day. [**Month (only) 8**] be consumed
   secondary to catheters. Appears to early to be HIT and really need
   heparin at this point. Will continue to follow.
   - trend, transfuse for significant bleed
   # Neurologic status: definitive therapy is dependent on patient
   neurological status. Neurology has been unable to fully weigh in due to
   concerns of patient still being sedated. Will readdress issue every
   morning at 8 AM with neurology team. CT head to eval for insult since
   L>R spontaneous movement.
   - continue to wean sedation as tolerated
   - await EEG results
   - appreciate neurology recommendations
   - CT head
   # Nutrtion: will start tube feeds per nutrition recs.
   # Cardiac Arrest: ?ventricular fibrillation (prior to OSH) likely
   secondary to severe acidosis.
   - no need for further anti-arrhythmics as patient
s acidosis is now
   corrected with tandemheart and ECMO
   - currently on amiodarone for Afib RVR
   # STEMI: patient continues have severe LAD and left main stenosis
   - await further clarification of patient
s neurologic status before
   progressing to CABG for definitive therapy.
   # Lactic acidosis
 resolved on ECMO
   # Hyperglycemia - No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] be on
   hydrocortisone w study protocol
   - Continue insulin gtt.
    # Goals of care
 will continue to actively involve the family to
   address goals of care. Once neuro status determined will have goals of
   care meeting.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male who was transferred from the operating room (OSH) after a syncope episode and chest pain. He has a history of 95% left main (LM) disease and 99% left anterior descending (LAD) stenosis, which was confirmed by cardiac catheterization. The patient underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with placement of stents in the LAD and left circumflex (LCx) arteries.

The patient developed cardiogenic shock after a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest, which was treated with a tandemheart device and extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO). He also required intubation and mechanical ventilation due to respiratory distress.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient is in cardiogenic shock, which is being treated with a tandemheart device and ECMO.
2. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient has developed hypoxemic respiratory failure, which is being treated with ECMO and mechanical ventilation.
3. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which is being treated with packed red blood cell (pRBC) transfusions.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has thrombocytopenia, which is being treated with platelet transfusions.
5. Neurologic status: The patient's neurologic status is unclear, and he is being sedated and intubated. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the head is planned to evaluate for any potential insult.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient has hyperglycemia, which is being treated with insulin therapy.
7. Lactic acidosis: The patient had lactic acidosis, which has resolved with ECMO therapy.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Ventricular fibrillation: The patient's history of ventricular fibrillation prior to OSH increases the risk of recurrence.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to increased oxygen requirements and potential complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia.
3. Bleeding: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia increase the risk of bleeding, particularly from the gastrointestinal tract or other sites.
4. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state and prolonged hospitalization increase the risk of infection, particularly pneumonia or sepsis.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of cardiac arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (Afib RVR), increases the risk of recurrent arrhythmias.
6. Stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA): The patient's neurologic status is unclear, and he is at risk of developing a stroke or TIA.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the following goals of care should be considered:

1. Stabilize the patient's cardiogenic shock and hypoxemic respiratory failure.
2. Optimize the patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia with transfusions and other supportive therapies.
3. Determine the patient's neurologic status and plan for further management.
4. Manage the patient's hyperglycemia and lactic acidosis.
5. Monitor for signs of infection, bleeding, and cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Consider the patient's goals of care and involve the family in the decision-making process.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU from the operating room after experiencing a syncope episode and chest pain. The patient underwent cardiac catheterization, which revealed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. The patient was treated with POBA LAD and LCx, and subsequently developed ventricular tachycardia (VT) that required two shocks in the catheterization lab. The patient was intubated for respiratory distress and was started on dopamine for hemodynamic support.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Cardiogenic shock: The patient was in cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest and was treated with a tandemheart device and ECMO. The patient's heart appears to be able to accomplish some of the workload, and the goal is to wean the tandemheart device as tolerated.
* Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient developed new respiratory failure likely secondary to catheter migration from the tandemheart device. The patient is being treated with ECMO, and the CXR shows worsened bilateral edema.
* Anemia: The patient required 3 units of packed red blood cells (pRBCs) yesterday, and the etiology of the anemia is unclear. The patient had significant oral and nasal bleeding, and the possibility of RP bleed or GI bleed is being considered.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient required 1 unit of platelets (plts) yesterday, and the etiology is unclear. The patient's platelet count remained relatively stable over the course of the day.
* Neurologic status: The patient's neurologic status is unclear due to concerns about the patient still being sedated. The goal is to wean sedation as tolerated and await EEG results.
* Nutritional support: The patient may require TPN or tube feeds for nutritional support.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient had a prior episode of ventricular fibrillation (VT) likely secondary to severe acidosis, which has now been corrected with the tandemheart and ECMO.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is a major factor in surgery decision, and the goal is to maximize the patient's respiratory status over the next couple of days.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiogenic shock and VT require close monitoring and treatment with the tandemheart device and ECMO.
* Bleeding complications: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia require close monitoring and treatment with blood transfusions as needed.
* Neurologic complications: The patient's unclear neurologic status requires close monitoring and treatment with sedation weaning and EEG results.
* Infection: The patient's respiratory failure and potential for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) require close monitoring and treatment with antibiotics as needed.
* Lactic acidosis: The patient's lactic acidosis requires close monitoring and treatment with ECMO and other supportive measures.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and treatment with multiple medical complications. The goal is to stabilize the patient's cardiogenic shock, respiratory failure, and other medical complications, and to determine the best course of treatment for the patient's underlying conditions.

   76F with [**Hospital 11306**] [**Hospital 1605**] transferred from OSH after syncope episode and chest
   pain, cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. POBA LAD
   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated. On [**1-2**] became bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT
   arrest. Had CPR for 2 mintes given 1mg atropine, 1mg epinephrine, 100
   of lidocaine. Received a tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to
   partially in the RA causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. [**1-3**] hematocrit
   and plt drop requiring transfusion.
   #Cardiogenic shock: Patient was in cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest.
   Yesterday, patient
s ventilator support was increased and tandem heart
   was shut off transiently, showing unassisted cardiac output of
   3.4-3.5.  PaO2 and PaCO2 remained reasonable.
   - Continue heparin gtt for tandem heart maintenance with goal ACT - 200
   - appreciate cardiac surgery recommendations
   - try removal of tandem heart today if patient continues to demonstrate
   hemodynamic stability.
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure: Thought to be due to pulmonary edema
   secondary to acute congestive heart failure, although hemorrhage,
   aspiration pneumonia and ARDS also on differential.  Patient does not
   meet ARDS criteria currently due to elevated wedge pressure but
   fulfills all other criteria. CXR showed improvement yesterday with
   aggressive diuresis, as did respiratory status yesterday on trial off
   of ECMO/tandem heart.
   -continue ECMO for now until removal of tandem heart.
   - CXR today to re-eval
   - ARDS net vent settings
   - Cover potential ventilator associated pneumonia with cefepime and
   vancomycin (day [**3-8**]), plan for 8 day course for VAP
   - Lasix gtt
   - CT torso final read pending.
   # Anemia: Unclear etiology. Required 1u pRBCs overnight. The patient
   had significant OP bleed. ENT evaluated and packed nasal and oral
   cavities. They will follow. Unlikely to explain total hct drop. Pt also
   has evidence of hemolysis, likely from external lines. No evidence of
   RP bleed on CT torso.
   - trend, transfuse if rapidly dropping hct, signs of hypoperfusion
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Unclear etiology. Required 1u plts overnight.
   Remained relatively stable over the course of the day. Likely secondary
   to mechanical lysis through tandem heart/echo. Appears to early to be
   HIT and really need heparin at this point. Will continue to follow.
   - trend, transfuse for significant bleed
   # Neurologic status: CT scan yesterday showed no evidence of acute
   infarction, although MRI is superior in detecting this.  Neurology has
   stated that it is not possible to prognosticate currently.  She is now
   moving all four extremities, responding as of yet to pain.
   -          appreciate neurology input.
   -          Will continue to follow her clinical exam.
   # Nutrtion: continue tube feeds per nutrition recs.
   # Atrial fibrillation: - currently on amiodarone loading for Afib RVR
   # STEMI: patient continues have severe LAD and left main stenosis
   - family meeting yesterday with plan for further stabilization before
   progressing to CABG for definitive therapy.
   # Hyperglycemia - No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] be on
   hydrocortisone w study protocol
   - Continue insulin gtt.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female who presented to the hospital with severe anteriolateral STEMI, resulting in cardiogenic shock. She underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with POBA LAD and LCx, and was subsequently intubated for respiratory distress. She developed ventricular tachycardia (VT) and had two episodes of shock in the catheterization lab, requiring tandem heart support and ECMO. The patient had a PEA arrest and was resuscitated with CPR and medications. She was transferred to the ICU for further management.

Current Status:

The patient is currently on ECMO and tandem heart support, with a goal of weaning off these therapies. Her vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 88/55 mmHg, heart rate of 92 bpm, and respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute. She is receiving fentanyl for pain management and midazolam for sedation. Her laboratory results show a mild anemia and thrombocytopenia, which are being monitored.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is a significant concern, and she may require further management with inotropes and vasopressors to maintain blood pressure and cardiac output.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and she may require further management with mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and bandemia may indicate the presence of sepsis, which could worsen her clinical status and increase her risk of mortality.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may increase her risk of bleeding, particularly if she requires invasive procedures or has a traumatic injury.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen her cardiogenic shock and increase her risk of bleeding.
6. Neurologic complications: The patient's PEA arrest and subsequent resuscitation may have caused neurologic damage, which could lead to cognitive impairment, paralysis, or other neurologic deficits.
7. Infection: The patient's respiratory failure and sepsis may increase her risk of developing pneumonia or other infections, which could worsen her clinical status and increase her risk of mortality.

Plan:

1. Continue ECMO and tandem heart support until the patient's cardiogenic shock is resolved.
2. Monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely to detect any changes or worsening of her clinical status.
3. Manage the patient's respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
4. Monitor the patient's thrombocytopenia and anemia, and transfuse blood products as necessary to maintain adequate hemostasis.
5. Continue antibiotics for sepsis and pneumonia, and monitor the patient's response to treatment.
6. Monitor the patient's neurologic status closely, and consult with neurology if any changes are noted.
7. Continue to provide supportive care, including pain management, sedation, and nutrition, to optimize the patient's comfort and quality of life.

   pain, cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. POBA LAD
   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated. On [**1-2**] became bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT
   arrest. Had CPR for 2 mintes given 1mg atropine, 1mg epinephrine, 100
   of lidocaine. Received a tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to
   partially in the RA causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. [**1-3**] hematocrit
   and plt drop requiring transfusion.
   #Cardiogenic shock: Patient was in cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest.
   Yesterday, patient
s ventilator support was increased and tandem heart
   was shut off transiently, showing unassisted cardiac output of
   3.4-3.5.  PaO2 and PaCO2 remained reasonable.
   - Continue heparin gtt for tandem heart maintenance with goal ACT - 200
   - appreciate cardiac surgery recommendations
   - try removal of tandem heart today if patient continues to demonstrate
   hemodynamic stability.
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure: Thought to be due to pulmonary edema
   secondary to acute congestive heart failure, although hemorrhage,
   aspiration pneumonia and ARDS also on differential.  Patient does not
   meet ARDS criteria currently due to elevated wedge pressure but
   fulfills all other criteria. CXR showed improvement yesterday with
   aggressive diuresis, as did respiratory status yesterday on trial off
   of ECMO/tandem heart.
   -continue ECMO for now until removal of tandem heart.
   - CXR today to re-eval
   - ARDS net vent settings
   - Cover potential ventilator associated pneumonia with cefepime and
   vancomycin (day [**3-8**]), plan for 8 day course for VAP
   - Lasix gtt
   - CT torso final read pending.
   # Anemia: Unclear etiology. Required 1u pRBCs overnight. The patient
   had significant OP bleed. ENT evaluated and packed nasal and oral
   cavities. They will follow. Unlikely to explain total hct drop. Pt also
   has evidence of hemolysis, likely from external lines. No evidence of
   RP bleed on CT torso.
   - trend, transfuse if rapidly dropping hct, signs of hypoperfusion
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Unclear etiology. Required 1u plts overnight.
   Remained relatively stable over the course of the day. Likely secondary
   to mechanical lysis through tandem heart/echo. Appears to early to be
   HIT and really need heparin at this point. Will continue to follow.
   - trend, transfuse for significant bleed
   # Neurologic status: CT scan yesterday showed no evidence of acute
   infarction, although MRI is superior in detecting this.  Neurology has
   stated that it is not possible to prognosticate currently.  She is now
   moving all four extremities, responding as of yet to pain.
   -          appreciate neurology input.
   -          Will continue to follow her clinical exam.
   # Nutrtion: continue tube feeds per nutrition recs.
   # Atrial fibrillation: - currently on amiodarone loading for Afib RVR
   # STEMI: patient continues have severe LAD and left main stenosis
   - family meeting yesterday with plan for further stabilization before
   progressing to CABG for definitive therapy.
   # Hyperglycemia - No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] be on
   hydrocortisone w study protocol
   - Continue insulin gtt.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female who presented to the hospital with severe anteriolateral STEMI, cardiogenic shock, and was intubated for respiratory distress. She underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with POBA LAD and LCx, and was supported with tandem heart and ECMO after experiencing a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic instability: The patient is still in cardiogenic shock, with a systolic blood pressure of 51 mmHg and a pulmonary artery diastolic pressure of 26 mmHg.
* Respiratory failure: The patient has hypoxemic respiratory failure, which is thought to be secondary to pulmonary edema due to acute congestive heart failure, although hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, and ARDS are also on the differential.
* Anemia: The patient has an unclear etiology of anemia, with a significant drop in hemoglobin level overnight, and is requiring transfusions.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient has thrombocytopenia, which is likely secondary to mechanical lysis through tandem heart/echo, and is requiring platelet transfusions.
* Neurologic status: The patient is moving all four extremities and responding to pain, but the neurology team is unable to prognosticate at this time.
* Hyperglycemia: The patient is hyperglycemic and is being treated with insulin.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Cardiogenic shock: The patient is already in cardiogenic shock, and further deterioration of her hemodynamic status could lead to organ dysfunction or failure.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure could worsen, leading to hypoxia and hypercapnia.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia could worsen, leading to further drops in hemoglobin levels and potential organ dysfunction.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia could worsen, leading to increased bleeding risk.
* Neurologic complications: The patient's neurologic status could worsen, leading to increased risk of brain injury or death.
* Infection: The patient is at risk of developing infections, particularly ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBSI).
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient is at risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, such as stress ulceration and bleeding.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, the following interventions should be considered:

* Continue heparin therapy to maintain the tandem heart and prevent thrombosis.
* Continue ECMO support until the patient is hemodynamically stable and can be weaned off.
* Continue aggressive diuresis to manage pulmonary edema and hypoxemia.
* Continue platelet and red blood cell transfusions as needed to manage anemia and thrombocytopenia.
* Monitor the patient's neurologic status closely and consider consultation with neurology for further management.
* Consider consultation with cardiology for further management of the patient's cardiac condition.
* Continue to monitor the patient's glucose levels and adjust insulin therapy as needed to manage hyperglycemia.
* Consider consultation with infectious disease for further management of potential infections.
* Consider consultation with gastroenterology for further management of potential gastrointestinal complications.

   76F with [**Hospital 11306**] [**Hospital 1605**] transferred from OSH after syncope episode and chest
   pain, cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. POBA LAD
   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated. On [**1-2**] became bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT
   arrest. Had CPR for 2 mintes given 1mg atropine, 1mg epinephrine, 100
   of lidocaine. Received a tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to
   partially in the RA causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. [**1-3**] hematocrit
   and plt drop requiring transfusion.
   #Cardiogenic shock: Patient was in cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest.
   Yesterday, patient
s ventilator support was increased and tandem heart
   was shut off transiently, showing unassisted cardiac output of
   3.4-3.5.  PaO2 and PaCO2 remained reasonable.
   - Continue heparin gtt for tandem heart maintenance with goal ACT - 200
   - appreciate cardiac surgery recommendations
   - try removal of tandem heart today if patient continues to demonstrate
   hemodynamic stability.
   - pressors ready at bedside at time of removal.
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure: Thought to be due to pulmonary edema
   secondary to acute congestive heart failure, although hemorrhage,
   aspiration pneumonia and ARDS also on differential.  Patient does not
   meet ARDS criteria currently due to elevated wedge pressure but
   fulfills all other criteria. CXR showed improvement yesterday with
   aggressive diuresis, as did respiratory status yesterday on trial off
   of ECMO/tandem heart.  Prelim read of CT torso shows bibasilar
   atelectasis, bilateral patchy infiltrates consistent with pulmonary
   edema or ARDS.
   -continue ECMO for now until removal of tandem heart.
   - CXR today to re-eval
   - ARDS net vent settings
   - Cover potential ventilator associated pneumonia with cefepime and
   vancomycin (day [**3-8**]), plan for 8 day course for VAP
   - Lasix gtt as tolerated, although will likely not tolerate after
   tandem heart removed.
   - CT torso final read pending.
   # Gram negative rods in sputum culture
   - will continue to cover broadly with cefepime, narrow coverage when
   speciation comes back.
   - consider discontinuing vancomycin.
   # Anemia: Unclear etiology. Required 1u pRBCs overnight. The patient
   had significant OP bleed. ENT evaluated and packed nasal and oral
   cavities. They will follow. Unlikely to explain total hct drop. Pt also
   has evidence of hemolysis, likely from external lines. No evidence of
   RP bleed on CT torso.
   - trend, transfuse if rapidly dropping hct, signs of hypoperfusion
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Unclear etiology. Required 1u plts overnight.
   Remained relatively stable over the course of the day. Likely secondary
   to mechanical lysis through tandem heart/echo. Appears to early to be
   HIT and really need heparin at this point. Will continue to follow.
   - trend, transfuse for significant bleed
   # Neurologic status: CT scan yesterday showed no evidence of acute
   infarction, although MRI is superior in detecting this.  Neurology has
   stated that it is not possible to prognosticate currently.  She is now
   moving all four extremities, responding as of yet minimally only to
   voice, more to pain.
   -          appreciate neurology input.
   -          Will continue to follow her clinical exam.
   # Nutrition: continue tube feeds per nutrition recs.
   # Atrial fibrillation: - currently on amiodarone loading for Afib RVR
   # STEMI: patient continues have severe LAD and left main stenosis
   - family meeting yesterday with plan for further stabilization before
   progressing to CABG for definitive therapy.
   #Dusky left leg
 will pull arterial femoral sheath today with removal
   of tandem heart.
   #Epistaxis, oropharynx bleeding
 re-consult ENT for further
   management.
   # Hyperglycemia - No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] be on
   hydrocortisone w study protocol.  Study drug now stopped as not on
   pressors.
   - Stop insulin gtt

 will continue to actively involve the family to

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female who presented with severe anteriolateral STEMI, cardiogenic shock, and required POBA LAD and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in the cath lab. She was intubated for respiratory distress and received dopamine for hemodynamic support. She experienced PEA arrest and was resuscitated with CPR, followed by initiation of ECMO. The patient has been receiving heparin, fentanyl, midazolam, and lasix infusions. She has a significant drop in hematocrit and platelets, requiring transfusions. She also has evidence of hemolysis and thrombocytopenia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock may worsen due to the severity of her heart disease, and she may require further invasive hemodynamic support.
2. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate due to pulmonary edema, aspiration pneumonia, or ARDS, requiring further ventilatory support.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen due to ongoing bleeding, hemolysis, or bone marrow suppression, requiring further transfusions.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen due to mechanical lysis, bleeding, or bone marrow suppression, requiring further platelet transfusions.
5. Neurological status: The patient's neurological status may deteriorate due to ongoing hypoxia, hypoperfusion, or secondary to her underlying heart disease, requiring further neurological evaluation.
6. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia, and further antibiotics may be necessary to cover potential pathogens.
7. Bleeding: The patient's bleeding may worsen due to ongoing anticoagulation, platelet dysfunction, or vascular injury, requiring further hemostatic support.
8. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may worsen due to stress, corticosteroid use, or other underlying medical conditions, requiring further glucose monitoring and management.
9. Dusky left leg: The patient's dusky left leg may worsen due to ongoing vascular insufficiency, requiring further evaluation and management.
10. Epistaxis and oropharynx bleeding: The patient's bleeding may worsen due to ongoing anticoagulation, platelet dysfunction, or vascular injury, requiring further hemostatic support.

ICU Care Plan:

1. Continue ECMO for hemodynamic support.
2. Monitor the patient's hemodynamic status closely and adjust therapy as needed.
3. Continue antibiotics for suspected VAP and ARDS.
4. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilatory support as needed.
5. Continue anticoagulation and platelet transfusions as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and adjust therapy as needed.
7. Continue glucose monitoring and management.
8. Monitor the patient's bleeding status closely and adjust therapy as needed.
9. Consider removing the tandem heart if the patient's hemodynamic status improves.
10. Continue to actively involve the family in goal-setting and decision-making.

   76F with [**Hospital 11306**] [**Hospital 1605**] transferred from OSH after syncope episode and chest
   pain, cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. POBA LAD
   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated. On [**1-2**] became bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT
   arrest. Had CPR for 2 mintes given 1mg atropine, 1mg epinephrine, 100
   of lidocaine. Received a tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to
   partially in the RA causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. [**1-3**] hematocrit
   and plt drop requiring transfusion. Removal of ECMO and tandem heart.
   Requiring multiple pressors - amiodarone.
   #Cardiogenic shock: Patient was in cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest.
   Yesterday were able to removed ECMO/TandemHeart. Currently on multiple
   pressors for pressure support.
   - Attempt to wean phenylephrine first
   - Continue presser support
   - Continue heparin gtt
   - Appreciate cardiac surgery recommendations
   - d/c lasix gtt
   - eventual high risk PCI vs CABG
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure: Thought to be due to pulmonary edema
   secondary to acute congestive heart failure, although hemorrhage,
   aspiration pneumonia and ARDS also on differential.  Patient does not
   meet ARDS criteria currently due to elevated wedge pressure but
   fulfills all other criteria. CXR showed improvement, as did respiratory
   status yesterday. CT - ARDS vs pulmonary edema.
   - decrease tidal volume to ARDS net goals (currently at 400 - too high)
   - cont FiO2 < 0.6 if possible
   - CXR today
   - cont cefepime and vancomycin day [**4-7**] for VAP
   - diurese if tolerated once pressors weaned
   # Gram negative rods in sputum culture
   - will continue to cover broadly with cefepime, narrow coverage when
   speciation comes back.
   - consider discontinuing vancomycin
   # Anemia: Unclear etiology. The patient had significant OP bleed.
   Suctioned blood from ETT. [**Month (only) 8**] need ENT to re-eval patient. No evidence
   of RP bleed on CT torso. Will watch today now that tandemheart is out
   if hct improves/stablizes.
   - trend, transfuse if rapidly dropping hct, signs of hypoperfusion
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Unclear etiology - likely secondary to
   tandemheart/ecmo. Remained relatively stable over the course of the
   day. Will continue to follow.
   - trend, transfuse for significant bleed
   # Neurologic status: CT scan yesterday showed no evidence of acute
   infarction, although MRI is superior in detecting this.  Neurology has
   stated that it is not possible to prognosticate currently.  She is now
   moving all four extremities, responding as of yet minimally only to
   voice, more to pain.
   - appreciate neurology input.
   - Will continue to follow her clinical exam.
   # Nutrition: continue tube feeds per nutrition recs.
   # Atrial fibrillation: - currently on amiodarone loading for Afib RVR
   - cont amio
   - attempt to keep beta adrenergics at a minimum if possible
   # STEMI: patient continues have severe LAD and left main stenosis - PCI
   vs CABG
   - family meeting yesterday
   #Dusky left leg
 will pull arterial femoral sheath today with removal
   of tandem heart.
   - will follow
   #Epistaxis, oropharynx bleeding
 re-consult ENT for further
   management.
   - ENT will follow in needed
   # Hyperglycemia - No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] be on
   hydrocortisone w study protocol.  Study drug now stopped as not on
   pressors.
   - Stop insulin gtt

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after experiencing a syncope episode and chest pain. She underwent cardiac catheterization, which showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She was intubated for respiratory distress and received dopamine for hemodynamic support. She developed cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest and required ECMO and tandemheart. She was eventually weaned off ECMO and tandemheart, but remains on multiple pressors.

The patient's current condition is:

* Cardiogenic shock: Patient is on multiple pressors for pressure support.
* Hypoxemic respiratory failure: Patient's respiratory status has improved, but she still requires mechanical ventilation.
* Anemia: Unclear etiology, but patient had significant OP bleed and suctioned blood from ETT.
* Thrombocytopenia: Unclear etiology, but patient's platelet count has remained relatively stable.
* Neurologic status: Patient is moving all four extremities, responding minimally to voice and pain.
* Atrial fibrillation: Patient is on amiodarone loading for Afib RVR.
* STEMI: Patient has severe LAD and left main stenosis, and is being considered for PCI vs CABG.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

* Cardiac arrest: Patient is at risk for cardiac arrest due to her underlying cardiac disease and the need for multiple pressors.
* Respiratory failure: Patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and she may require further mechanical ventilation or other respiratory support.
* Sepsis: Patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to her underlying illness and the presence of multiple lines and tubes.
* Bleeding: Patient has had significant bleeding in the past, and is at risk for further bleeding due to her thrombocytopenia and the need for anticoagulation.
* Neurologic decline: Patient's neurologic status is still unstable, and she may experience further decline due to her underlying illness or the need for further mechanical ventilation.
* Infection: Patient is at risk for developing infection due to her underlying illness and the presence of multiple lines and tubes.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after a syncope episode and chest pain. She underwent cardiac catheterization and was found to have 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She received a tandemheart in the cath lab, but it was retracted partially into the RA, causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated, and the patient was in cardiogenic shock.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 101.7, HR 80, BP 100/55, RR 18, SpO2 99%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CO 3.6, CI 2.6, SVR -3,479 dynes*sec/cm5
* Respiratory support: Endotracheal tube, CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow ventilator mode, PEEP 12 cmH2O, FiO2 60%
* Laboratory results: WBC 12.6, Hct 27.5, Plt 70, Cr 1.1, TCO2 32, Glucose 199
* Imaging: CXR shows minimal decrease of pre-existing retrocardiac atelectasis, no newly appeared parenchymal changes
* Microbiology: Blood cx - NGTD, pending; Urine cx - E. Coli; Sputum cx - gram - rods
* Assessment and plan:
	+ Cardiogenic shock: Patient was in cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest. Currently on multiple pressors for pressure support.
	+ Hypoxemic respiratory failure: Thought to be due to pulmonary edema secondary to acute congestive heart failure. CXR showed improvement, as did respiratory status yesterday.
	+ Gram negative rods in sputum culture: Will continue to cover broadly with cefepime, narrow coverage when speciation comes back.
	+ Anemia: Unclear etiology. Trend, transfuse if rapidly dropping hct, signs of hypoperfusion.
	+ Thrombocytopenia: Unclear etiology. Trend, transfuse for significant bleed.
	+ Neurologic status: CT scan yesterday showed no evidence of acute infarction. Neurology has stated that it is not possible to prognosticate currently.
	+ Nutrition: Continue tube feeds per nutrition recs.
	+ Atrial fibrillation: Currently on amiodarone loading for Afib RVR. Start po amio, attempt to keep beta adrenergics at a minimum if possible.
	+ STEMI: Patient continues to have severe LAD and left main stenosis - PCI vs CABG.
	+ Dusky left leg: Will pull arterial femoral sheath today with removal of tandem heart.
	+ Epistaxis, oropharynx bleeding: Re-consult ENT for further management.
	+ Hyperglycemia: No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic. Will be on hydrocortisone w study protocol. Study drug now stopped as not on pressors.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's current status include:

* Cardiogenic shock: Continued need for multiple pressors for pressure support, potential for further hemodynamic instability.
* Hypoxemic respiratory failure: Continued need for respiratory support, potential for further deterioration in oxygenation.
* Gram negative rods in sputum culture: Potential for further infection, need for continued antimicrobial coverage.
* Anemia: Potential for further anemia, need for continued transfusion support.
* Thrombocytopenia: Potential for further bleeding, need for continued platelet transfusion support.
* Neurologic status: Potential for further neurological deterioration, need for continued close monitoring.
* Atrial fibrillation: Potential for further arrhythmia, need for continued anticoagulation and rate control.
* STEMI: Potential for further cardiac damage, need for continued cardiac catheterization and potential revascularization.
* Dusky left leg: Potential for further bleeding, need for continued close monitoring.
* Epistaxis, oropharynx bleeding: Potential for further bleeding, need for continued close monitoring.
* Hyperglycemia: Potential for further hyperglycemia, need for continued close monitoring and potential adjustment of insulin therapy.

Based on the patient's current status and potential medical complications, the following plan should be considered:

* Continue close monitoring of the patient's hemodynamic status, respiratory status, and neurological status.
* Continue antimicrobial coverage for the suspected gram negative rods in the sputum culture.
* Continue transfusion support for the patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia.
* Continue close monitoring of the patient's neurological status and potential for further deterioration.
* Continue cardiac catheterization and potential revascularization for the patient's STEMI.
* Continue close monitoring of the patient's left leg for potential further bleeding.
* Continue close monitoring of the patient's oropharynx for potential further bleeding.
* Continue close monitoring of the patient's hyperglycemia and potential adjustment of insulin therapy.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female who was transferred to the ICU from the operating room after a syncope episode and chest pain. She underwent cardiac catheterization, which showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She was intubated for respiratory distress and is currently on multiple pressors for hemodynamic support.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Hypoxemic respiratory failure is likely secondary to pulmonary edema, acute congestive heart failure, or aspiration pneumonia. The patient is on a ventilator with a tidal volume of 280 mL and FiO2 of 60%.
* Cardiovascular: The patient is in cardiogenic shock after a PEA arrest. She is on multiple pressors, including vasopressin and phenylephrine, and is receiving dopamine for hemodynamic support.
* Hematological: The patient has leukocytosis, anemia, and thrombocytopenia, which may be related to the underlying medical conditions or the use of blood products.
* Neurological: The patient has a decreased level of consciousness and is unable to respond to verbal stimuli. She is currently sedated with propofol and is being monitored for signs of neurologic deterioration.
* Renal: The patient has a decreased creatinine level and is receiving diuretics to manage fluid overload.
* Infection: The patient has a positive sputum culture for Klebsiella pneumoniae, which is pan-sensitive.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further respiratory distress.
* Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock may persist or worsen, leading to further hemodynamic instability.
* Infection: The patient's positive sputum culture may indicate a more widespread infection, which could lead to sepsis or organ failure.
* Neurological deterioration: The patient's decreased level of consciousness and sedation may lead to further neurological deterioration.
* Renal failure: The patient's decreased creatinine level and diuretic therapy may indicate impending renal failure.
* Bleeding: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia may increase the risk of bleeding, particularly with the use of anticoagulant therapy.

The patient's goals of care are to be DNR (do not resuscitate) and to receive ICU care. The patient's family has been informed of the patient's condition and has agreed to the DNR status.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following:

The patient, a 76-year-old female, was admitted to the ICU after experiencing syncope and chest pain. She underwent cardiac catheterization, which revealed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She was intubated for respiratory distress and dopamine was started for hemodynamic support. She developed bradycardia and required atropine and epinephrine. She was also treated with amiodarone and phenylephrine for cardiogenic shock.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely secondary to pulmonary edema secondary to acute congestive heart failure, although hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, and ARDS are also on the differential. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 280 mL and a FiO2 of 60%.
* Cardiovascular: Cardiogenic shock, with the patient requiring multiple pressors for pressure support. She is currently on vasopressin and phenylephrine.
* Hematological: Leukocytosis, with a white blood cell count of 16.8 K/uL. She is also anemic, with a hematocrit of 27.3%, and thrombocytopenic, with a platelet count of 113 K/uL.
* Neurological: The patient is currently sedated and has limited neurological function, with minimal responsiveness to voice and pain.
* Renal: The patient's creatinine level is 0.5 mg/dL, and her urine output is 100 cc/hr.
* Infectious: The patient has a positive blood culture for Klebsiella pneumoniae and is being treated with cefepime and vancomycin.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Cardiogenic shock and cardiac arrest
* Respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Sepsis and septic shock
* Leukocytosis and neutropenia
* Anemia and bleeding
* Thrombocytopenia and bleeding
* Neurological deterioration and brain death
* Renal failure and acute kidney injury
* Infectious complications, such as pneumonia and sepsis

The patient's goals of care are to continue ICU care, with a focus on maintaining hemodynamic stability, managing respiratory and cardiovascular function, and preventing infectious complications. The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate).

   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated. On [**1-2**] became bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT
   arrest. Had CPR for 2 mintes given 1mg atropine, 1mg epinephrine, 100
   of lidocaine. Received a tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to
   partially in the RA causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. [**1-3**] hematocrit
   and plt drop requiring transfusion. Removal of ECMO and tandem heart.
   Requiring multiple pressors - amiodarone and phenylephrine.
   #. Hypoxemic respirtory failure: Likely secondary to pulmonary edema
   secondary to acute congestive heart failure, although hemorrhage,
   aspiration pneumonia, ARDS also on differential. The patient does not
   meet ARDS criteria although difficult to exclude. CXR is stable. [**1-6**]
   patient became tachypenic to 40, seemed agitated. Started sedation with
   propofol. Required relatively high doses which dropped pressures
   requiring us to start phenylephrine.
   - maintain tidal volume in ARDS net goals
   - maintain FiO2 < 0.6
   - d/c propofol, start fentanyl and versed if needed - hopefully will
   require less to sedate
   - CXR today
   - cont cefepime and vancomycin day [**5-8**] (although increased cefepime
   dose, may have been under treating)
   - f/u vanc trough
   - diurese as tolerated
   - frequent ABG
   #. Cardiogenic shock: The patient was in cardiogenic shock after PEA
   arrest. S/p removal of ECMO and tendemheart. Currently on multiple
   pressors for pressure support. Hopefully will be able to wean
   phenylephrine when off propofol.
   - change sedation as above

   - continue heparin gtt

   - PCI vs CABG

   - trend hct

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following:

The patient, a 76-year-old female, was admitted to the ICU with a history of syncope episode and chest pain, and was diagnosed with 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with VT s/p shock twice in the cath lab, intubated for respiratory distress, and received dopamine for hemodynamic support. She developed cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest and was treated with vasopressors and ECMO. The patient's condition has been complex, with multiple medical complications, including:

1. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count continues to increase, and she has been febrile. Cultures were sent for tip and sputum, and C. diff was negative.
2. Cardiogenic shock: The patient was in cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest and has been treated with vasopressors and ECMO. She is currently on multiple pressors for pressure support.
3. Anemia: The patient's hematocrit and platelet count have dropped, and she has required transfusions.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, likely secondary to tandemheart/ecmo.
5. Neurologic status: The patient has minimal responsiveness and is moving all four extremities. Her neurologic status is uncertain.
6. Atrial fibrillation: The patient developed atrial fibrillation, which was treated with amiodarone.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels have been elevated, and she is being treated with insulin.
8. Dusky left leg: The patient's left leg was dusky, and an arterial femoral sheath was pulled to improve blood flow.
9. Epistaxis, oropharynx bleeding: The patient has had bleeding from her oropharynx, and ENT was consulted for further management.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Infection: The patient's febrile state and leukocytosis increase the risk of infection.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and cardiogenic shock increase the risk of further cardiac arrhythmias.
3. Hemorrhage: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia increase the risk of bleeding.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and hypoxemic respiratory failure increase the risk of further respiratory failure.
5. Neurologic deterioration: The patient's uncertain neurologic status increases the risk of further neurologic deterioration.
6. Sepsis: The patient's febrile state and leukocytosis increase the risk of sepsis.

The patient's goals of care are to continue ICU care, nutrition, and glycemic control, and to manage her multiple medical complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after a syncope episode and chest pain. She has undergone multiple interventions, including cardiac catheterization, percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), and extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic instability: The patient is receiving multiple pressors, including vasopressin and phenylephrine, to maintain blood pressure.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 280 mL and a PEEP of 8 cmH2O.
* Septic shock: The patient has grown Klebsiella pneumoniae from her sputum, and her leukocytosis is increasing with a left shift.
* Cardiogenic shock: The patient had cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest and is now relatively resolved.
* Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is 8.4 g/dL, and her hematocrit is 26%.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is 138,000/μL.
* Neurologic status: The patient is responding minimally to voice and pain, but her neurologic exam is limited due to sedation.
* Atrial fibrillation: The patient has developed atrial fibrillation, which is being treated with amiodarone.
* Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose level is elevated, and she is being treated with insulin.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Continued hemodynamic instability and the need for multiple pressors
* Development of ARDS or pulmonary edema
* Progression of septic shock or development of multi-organ dysfunction syndrome
* Hemorrhagic complications due to thrombocytopenia or anemia
* Neurologic deterioration or development of neurologic deficits
* Worsening of hyperglycemia or development of diabetic ketoacidosis
* Infection or sepsis due to the patient's underlying medical conditions or invasive devices

Given the patient's complex medical status, it is essential to continue to monitor her closely and adjust her treatment plan as needed to prevent or manage potential complications.

   76F with [**Hospital 11306**] [**Hospital 1605**] transferred from OSH after syncope episode and chest
   pain, cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. POBA LAD
   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated. On [**1-2**] became bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT
   arrest. Had CPR for 2 mintes given 1mg atropine, 1mg epinephrine, 100
   of lidocaine. Received a tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to
   partially in the RA causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. [**1-3**] hematocrit
   and plt drop requiring transfusion. Removal of ECMO and tandem heart.
   Requiring multiple pressors - vasopressin and phenylephrine.
   #. Hypoxemic respiratory failure:
   Likely secondary to pulmonary edema secondary to acute congestive heart
   failure, although hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, ARDS also on
   differential. The patient does not meet ARDS criteria although
   difficult to exclude.  Continues on sedation with propofol, requiring
   phenylephrine.  Failed 3 pressure support trials.  Increased O2
   requirment this AM.  Respiratory failure may be partially secondary to
   pneumonia.  Has known Klebsiella pneumonia.
   - maintain tidal volume in ARDS net goals
   - will attempt pressure support trial to see if patient is able to
   maintain ventilation on her own.
   - wean as tolerated
   - f/u sputum cultures
   - CT chest (while doing CT abdomen for pancreatitis / acalculus
   cholecystitis eval)
   # Distributive shock:
   Patient is now demonstrating sepsis physiology with decent cardiac
   output but low SVR, likely septic, but consider that it may be
   secondary to pancreatitis.  Consider also acalculus cholecystitis.
   Likely source is pneumonia as sputum has grown out klebsiella x3,
   pan-sensitive, but concerning because this bacterium grew while patient
   on cefepime (underdosed).  Abscess unlikely because of negative CT on
   [**1-4**]. Pt continues to have increasing leukocytosis.  C diff negative.
   Central line replaced on [**2142-1-7**].  Pan-cultured again yesterday.  ID
   consulted.  Abx switched from meropenum/cipro/vanc to vanc/zosyn.
   Increased pressor requirement overnight and stable WBC.
   -          f/u sputum culture w new sensitivities
   -          continue vasopressin, phenylephrine as needed to maintain
   pressures.
   -  abdominal ultrasound to eval pancreas and gallbladder
   - CT abdomen/pelvis/sinus
   .
   # Pancreatitis:
   Patient grimaced in pain when abdomen pressed.  Lipase 220. Started
   fentanyl boluses for comfort
   -          trend pancreatic enzymes
   -          abdominal ultrasound today
   -          continue fentanyl boluses as needed and NPO (no tube feeds)
   except meds
   -          check triglycerides
   .
   #. Cardiogenic shock , s/p STEMI:
   The patient was in cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest. S/p removal of
   ECMO and tendemheart. Now relatively resolved after stunned myocardium
   had chance to recover s/p STEMI.
   - continue vasopressin and phenylephrine
   - continue heparin gtt for potential LV thrombus.
   - PCI vs CABG when stable ; might need MVR if got CABG
   - low dose metoprolol 12.5mg tid
   #. Anemia:
   Unclear etiology.  Hct stable at 25.  Some bleeding from OP although
   doesn't appear to be large volume and appears to be dark, old blood.
   ENT aware of patient and will stop by if asked. CT torso without
   evidence of intraabdominal bleed. Tandemheart has been removed.
   - trending hct
   - transfuse if evidence of bleed or signs of hypoperfusion
   #. Neurologic status:
   CT scan showed no evidence of acute infarction, although MRI is
   superior in detecting this.  Neurology has stated that it is not
   possible to prognosticate currently.  She appeared to respond to voice
   yesterday, maybe tracking eyes but not moving extremities, responding
   minimally only to voice, more to pain.
   - appreciate neurology input
   - will continue to follow her clinical exam.
   - family will try to use Tagalog phrases in case she lost her second
   language
   - consider LP in the future, though meningitis unlikely
   - CT Head (while getting CT sinus/abd/chest)
   # Nutrition:  NPO for pancreatitis
   # Atrial fibrillation: -
   - continue on amiodarone per oral 400mg [**Hospital1 **] and switch to 200mg at end
   of week
   -          Beta blaocker as above.
   #Epistaxis, oropharynx bleeding
   - ENT will follow if needed
   # Hyperglycemia
   No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] have been on hydrocortisone w
   study protocol.  Study drug now stopped.  Remains hyperglycemic however
   over past several days.
