7. Regular administration of antibiotics to treat any suspected infections.
8. Close monitoring of blood pressure and heart rate to detect any changes in hemodynamic status.
9. Regular review of the patient's medications and dosages to ensure optimal therapy.

It is essential to continue the patient's treatment plan and monitor their progress closely to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   76F with [**Hospital 11306**] [**Hospital 1605**] transferred from OSH after syncope episode and chest
   pain, cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. POBA LAD
   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated after patient presents self cooled and in coma. On [**1-2**] became
   bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT arrest. Received a
   tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to partially in the RA
   causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. Removal of ECMO and tandem heart.
   Weaned pressors now only on phenylephrine. Improved mental status.
   Trach placed. To PCI soon
   #. Coronary Artery Disease:
   Patient is s/p STEMI and cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest.   s/p PCI
   [**1-17**] of LMCA. On Intra-aortic balloon pump s/p PCI.
   - continue plavix
   - continue aspirin
   - continue statin
   - heparin gtt continued
   - wean IABP; place on 1:2 this AM and remove after Bronch
   - continue low dose beta blocker with pressor on for blood pressure
   support
   #. Hypoxemic respiratory failure:
   Likely secondary to pulmonary edema secondary to acute congestive heart
   failure, although hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, ARDS also on
   differential.  Pressure support 15/6 this morning after having received
   fluids in Cath.  Wedge pressure during Cath yesterday was elevated into
   30s -- pt needs diuresis.
   - restart lasix drip after bolus ; goal -2L for today
   - giving one dose acetazolamide in addition in setting of metabolic
   alkalosis
   - trach stitches can be removed [**1-19**]
   #. Metabolic Alkalosis:
   pH trending upwards on blood gases overnight.  Need to be careful of
   further contraction alkalosis with diuresing further with lasix in the
   setting of metabolic alkalosis.   Consider RTA type 4 which could also
   account for possible potassium wasting.  AM cortisol  yesterday was
   within normal limits.
   - one dose acetazolamide
   #. Infectious disease:
   Currently requiring phenylephrine. ID has been following.  Patient
   appeared to respond well to meropenem but has received full course
   antibiotics.  Unclear what source of distributive shock is, may not be
   infectious.  AM cortisol within normal limits.  WBC stable.  Switched
   to ceftriaxone yesterday.   Temperatures in 99s over last 24 hours.
   - trend WBC, Temp
   - follow up cultures, beta glucan and galactomannan, low suspicion
   - culture if spikes
   - Bronch by Thoracics/IP to get BAL and clean old blood out of lungs
   #. Atrial fibrillation:
   Has been recurrent and intermittent.  Had no further episodes over
   atrial fibrillation overnight.  Has been Amiodarone IV loaded in the
   past.
   - cont telemetry
   - continue low dose beta blocker
   #. Pancreatitis:
   Lipase was elevated although now appears resolved. No longer needing
   fentanyl boluses for pain control. TG normal. Abdominal ultrasound
   shows no evidence of stones. GI consulted.  Exam is benign.
   - restarted tube feeds last night; holding for bronchoscopy
   #Acute Kidney injury:
   Patient
s creatinine is now at 1.1, trending down from peak of 2.
   Presented w Cr 1.0 on admission. Making good urine to PO lasix.
   Received mucomyst x5 doses prior to Cath.  Hypokalemia does not just
   appear to be associated with diuresis; consider potassium loss through
   kidneys.
   - replete lytes PRN
   - continue to monitor post Cath ; risk of contrast-induced nephropathy
   starting up to 48 hours later
   #. Anemia:
   CT torso without evidence of intraabdominal bleed. Tandem heart, which
   appeared associated with anemia, has been removed.  unclear etiology,
   but will transfuse as needed.  Old blood suctioned out of trach tube
   persistently but not as much as before, no active bleed.  Hct stable
   for now.
   -          Cont to monitor
   #. Neurologic status:
   Patient is now very responsive and participatory, moves toes and arms
   well, turns head and tries to speak.  CT head shows no evidence of
   stroke.
   - will continue to follow her clinical exam.
   # Nutrition:
   - restart tube feeds again slowly after Bronch today
   #Epistaxis, oropharynx
 no acute bleeding, has old clots
   - Thoracics to do Bronch
   # Hyperglycemia:
   No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] have been on hydrocortisone w
   study protocol.  Study drug now stopped.  Remains hyperglycemic however
   over past several days.
   - ISS
    # Goals of care
 patient now back to full code.  Speech and swallow
   for passy-muir valve.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with syncope and chest pain, diagnosed with STEMI and cardiogenic shock. She underwent PCI of LMCA and LAD, and was placed on intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP). She has a history of atrial fibrillation, and is currently on heparin, plavix, and aspirin. She has also been diagnosed with hypoxemic respiratory failure, metabolic alkalosis, and acute kidney injury.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is likely to worsen due to her underlying cardiogenic shock and pulmonary edema.
2. Infection: The patient has received full course of antibiotics, but her temperature is still in the 99s, and she may have an underlying infection that needs to be treated.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, and may be at risk for further cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Kidney injury: The patient's creatinine is trending down, but she may still be at risk for further kidney injury due to her underlying cardiogenic shock and acute kidney injury.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status is improving, but she may still be at risk for further neurological complications due to her underlying cardiogenic shock and hypoxemic respiratory failure.
6. Bleeding: The patient has had bleeding episodes in the past, and may be at risk for further bleeding due to her underlying cardiogenic shock and anticoagulation therapy.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient has been hyperglycemic for several days, and may be at risk for further hyperglycemia due to her underlying cardiogenic shock and stress response.
8. Pancreatitis: The patient's lipase was elevated in the past, and she may still be at risk for further pancreatitis due to her underlying cardiogenic shock and stress response.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her oxygen therapy as needed.
2. Continue to treat the patient's underlying infection with antibiotics, and consider adding additional therapy if her temperature does not improve.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac arrhythmias and adjust her anti-arrhythmic therapy as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust her fluid management and diuretic therapy as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust her sedation and pain management as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's bleeding risk and adjust her anticoagulation therapy as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's hyperglycemia and adjust her insulin therapy as needed.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's pancreatitis risk and adjust her pain management and nutritional therapy as needed.

   Mg++:2.1 mg/dL, PO4:2.1 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   76F with [**Hospital 11306**] [**Hospital 1605**] transferred from OSH after syncope episode and chest
   pain, cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. POBA LAD
   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated after patient presents self cooled and in coma. On [**1-2**] became
   bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT arrest. Received a
   tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to partially in the RA
   causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. Removal of ECMO and tandem heart.
   Weaned pressors now only on phenylephrine. Improved mental status.
   Trach placed. To PCI soon
   #. Coronary Artery Disease:
   Patient is s/p STEMI and cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest.   s/p PCI
   [**1-17**] of LMCA. On Intra-aortic balloon pump s/p PCI.
   - continue plavix
   - continue aspirin
   - continue statin
   - heparin gtt continued
   - wean IABP; place on 1:2 this AM and remove after Bronch
   - continue low dose beta blocker with pressor on for blood pressure
   support
   #. Hypoxemic respiratory failure:
   Likely secondary to pulmonary edema secondary to acute congestive heart
   failure, although hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, ARDS also on
   differential.  Pressure support 15/6 this morning after having received
   fluids in Cath.  Wedge pressure during Cath yesterday was elevated into
   30s -- pt needs diuresis.
   - restart lasix drip after bolus ; goal -2L for today
   - giving one dose acetazolamide in addition in setting of metabolic
   alkalosis
   - trach stitches can be removed [**1-19**]
   #. Metabolic Alkalosis:
   pH trending upwards on blood gases overnight.  Need to be careful of
   further contraction alkalosis with diuresing further with lasix in the
   setting of metabolic alkalosis.   Consider RTA type 4 which could also
   account for possible potassium wasting.  AM cortisol  yesterday was
   within normal limits.
   - one dose acetazolamide
   #. Infectious disease:
   Currently requiring phenylephrine. ID has been following.  Patient
   appeared to respond well to meropenem but has received full course
   antibiotics.  Unclear what source of distributive shock is, may not be
   infectious.  AM cortisol within normal limits.  WBC stable.  Switched
   to ceftriaxone yesterday.   Temperatures in 99s over last 24 hours.
   - trend WBC, Temp
   - follow up cultures, beta glucan and galactomannan, low suspicion
   - culture if spikes
   - Bronch by Thoracics/IP to get BAL and clean old blood out of lungs
   #. Atrial fibrillation:
   Has been recurrent and intermittent.  Had no further episodes over
   atrial fibrillation overnight.  Has been Amiodarone IV loaded in the
   past.
   - cont telemetry
   - continue low dose beta blocker
   #. Pancreatitis:
   Lipase was elevated although now appears resolved. No longer needing
   fentanyl boluses for pain control. TG normal. Abdominal ultrasound
   shows no evidence of stones. GI consulted.  Exam is benign.
   - restarted tube feeds last night; holding for bronchoscopy
   #Acute Kidney injury:
   Patient
s creatinine is now at 1.1, trending down from peak of 2.
   Presented w Cr 1.0 on admission. Making good urine to PO lasix.
   Received mucomyst x5 doses prior to Cath.  Hypokalemia does not just
   appear to be associated with diuresis; consider potassium loss through
   kidneys.
   - replete lytes PRN
   - continue to monitor post Cath ; risk of contrast-induced nephropathy
   starting up to 48 hours later
   #. Anemia:
   CT torso without evidence of intraabdominal bleed. Tandem heart, which
   appeared associated with anemia, has been removed.  unclear etiology,
   but will transfuse as needed.  Old blood suctioned out of trach tube
   persistently but not as much as before, no active bleed.  Hct stable
   for now.
   -          Cont to monitor
   #. Neurologic status:
   Patient is now very responsive and participatory, moves toes and arms
   well, turns head and tries to speak.  CT head shows no evidence of
   stroke.
   - will continue to follow her clinical exam.
   # Nutrition:
   - restart tube feeds again slowly after Bronch today
   #Epistaxis, oropharynx
 no acute bleeding, has old clots
   - Thoracics to do Bronch
   # Hyperglycemia:
   No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] have been on hydrocortisone w
   study protocol.  Study drug now stopped.  Remains hyperglycemic however
   over past several days.
   - ISS
    # Goals of care
 patient now back to full code.  Speech and swallow
   for passy-muir valve.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2142-1-1**] 05:05 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2142-1-7**] 02:02 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:

   Code status: Full code

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease, who presented to the hospital with syncope and chest pain. She underwent cardiac catheterization, which showed 95% LMCA and 99% LAD stenosis. She was intubated for respiratory distress and received dopamine for hemodynamic support. She developed bradycardia, PEA arrest, and was treated with atropine and ECMO. She was weaned off ECMO and tandem heart, and is currently on phenylephrine for blood pressure support.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 37.4°C, HR 100 bpm, BP 104/52 mmHg, RR 21 insp/min, SpO2 100%
* Respiratory support: Pressure support 15 cmH2O, FiO2 40%
* Cardiovascular: Sinus tachycardia, BP 104/52 mmHg
* Neurologic: Alert and responsive, moves toes and arms well, turns head and tries to speak
* Laboratory results: WBC 10.6 K/uL, Hct 28.2%, Cr 1.1 mg/dL, Glucose 103 mg/dL

Potential medical complications:

* Hypoxemic respiratory failure: likely secondary to pulmonary edema secondary to acute congestive heart failure
* Metabolic alkalosis: pH trending upwards on blood gases overnight, need to be careful of further contraction alkalosis with diuresis
* Infectious disease: unclear what source of distributive shock is, may not be infectious
* Atrial fibrillation: has been recurrent and intermittent
* Pancreatitis: lipase was elevated, but now appears resolved
* Acute kidney injury: patient's creatinine is now at 1.1, trending down from peak of 2
* Anemia: unclear etiology, but will transfuse as needed
* Neurologic status: patient is now very responsive and participatory, but will continue to follow her clinical exam
* Hyperglycemia: patient has been on hydrocortisone with study protocol, but remains hyperglycemic over past several days

Plan:

* Continue plavix, aspirin, and statin
* Wean IABP and place on 1:2 this AM and remove after bronch
* Continue low-dose beta blocker with pressor on for blood pressure support
* Restart lasix drip after bolus; goal -2L for today
* Give one dose acetazolamide in addition in setting of metabolic alkalosis
* Trend WBC and temperature
* Follow up cultures, beta glucan and galactomannan, low suspicion
* Culture if spikes
* Bronch by Thoracics/IP to get BAL and clean old blood out of lungs
* Continue telemetry and low-dose beta blocker
* Restart tube feeds last night; holding for bronchoscopy
* Replete lytes PRN
* Continue to monitor post-Cath; risk of contrast-induced nephropathy starting up to 48 hours later
* Cont to monitor anemia
* Will continue to follow patient's clinical exam
* Restart tube feeds again slowly after bronch today
* ISS
* Goals of care: patient is now back to full code, speech and swallow for passy-muir valve.

   Assessment and Plan
   76F with [**Hospital 11306**] [**Hospital 1605**] transferred from OSH after syncope episode and chest
   pain, cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. POBA LAD
   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated after patient presents self cooled and in coma. On [**1-2**] became
   bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT arrest. Received a
   tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to partially in the RA
   causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. Removal of ECMO and tandem heart.
   Weaned pressors now only on phenylephrine. Improved mental status.
   Trach placed. Now s/p PCI with stent to left main, jailed LAD with
   balloon espansion with good flow.
   #. Coronary Artery Disease:
   Patient is s/p STEMI and cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest.   s/p PCI
   [**1-17**] of LMCA. On Intra-aortic balloon pump s/p PCI.
   - continue plavix
   - continue aspirin
   - continue statin
   - continue low dose beta blocker with pressor on for blood pressure
   support
   #. Hypoxemic respiratory failure:
   Likely secondary to pulmonary edema secondary to acute congestive heart
   failure, although hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, ARDS also on
   differential.
   - hold lasix today.
   - giving one dose acetazolamide in addition in setting of metabolic
   alkalosis
   - trach stitches can be removed [**1-19**]
   #. Metabolic Alkalosis:
   pH trending upwards on blood gases overnight.  Need to be careful of
   further contraction alkalosis with diuresing further with lasix in the
   setting of metabolic alkalosis.   Consider RTA type 4 which could also
   account for possible potassium wasting.  AM cortisol  yesterday was
   within normal limits.
   - acetazolamide prn
   #. Fever: Patient appeared to respond well to meropenem but has
   received full course antibiotics.  Unclear what source of distributive
   shock is, may not be infectious.  AM cortisol within normal limits.
   WBC stable.  Spiked another temperature this AM.
   - follow up cultures, beta glucan and galactomannan, low suspicion
   - pan culture.
   - re-site central line.
   #. Atrial fibrillation:
   Has been recurrent and intermittent.  Had no further episodes over
   atrial fibrillation overnight.  Has been Amiodarone IV loaded in the
   past.
   - cont telemetry
   - continue low dose beta blocker
   #. Pancreatitis:
   Lipase was elevated although now appears resolved. No longer needing
   fentanyl boluses for pain control. TG normal. Abdominal ultrasound
   shows no evidence of stones. GI consulted.  Exam is benign.
   - apparently resolved.
   #Acute Kidney injury:
   Patient
s creatinine is now at 1.3 trending down from peak of 2.
   Presented w Cr 1.0 on admission. Making good urine to PO lasix.
   Received mucomyst x5 doses prior to Cath.  Hypokalemia does not just
   appear to be associated with diuresis; consider potassium loss through
   kidneys.
   - replete lytes PRN
   - continue to monitor post Cath ; risk of contrast-induced nephropathy
   starting up to 48 hours later
   #. Anemia:
   CT torso without evidence of intraabdominal bleed. Tandem heart, which
   appeared associated with anemia, has been removed.  unclear etiology,
   but will transfuse as needed.  Old blood suctioned out of trach tube
   persistently but not as much as before, no active bleed.  Hct stable
   for now.  Guiaic positive today.
   -          transfuse as needed.
   -          Pm hematocrit.
   #. Neurologic status:
   Patient is now very responsive and participatory, moves toes and arms
   well, turns head and tries to speak.  CT head shows no evidence of
   stroke.
   - will continue to follow her clinical exam.
   # Nutrition:
   - continue tube feeds.
   #Epistaxis, oropharynx
 no acute bleeding, has old clots
   - bronch clear of blood.
   # Hyperglycemia:
   No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] have been on hydrocortisone w
   study protocol.  Study drug now stopped.  Remains hyperglycemic however
   over past several days.
   - ISS

 patient now back to full code.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after experiencing a syncope episode and chest pain. She underwent cardiac catheterization, which revealed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She was intubated for respiratory distress and received dopamine for hemodynamic support. She was also started on ECMO and tandem heart, but these were later removed.

Current vital signs:

* Temperature: 37.4°C (99.3°F)
* Heart rate: 100 bpm (normal range: 84-113 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 104/52 mmHg (normal range: 72-124/51-90 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 21 breaths per minute (normal range: 16-28 breaths per minute)
* SpO2: 100% (normal range: 95-100%)

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 10.6 K/uL (normal range: 4.5-11.0 K/uL)
* Hemoglobin: 7.7 g/dL (normal range: 12.0-16.0 g/dL)
* Platelet count: 248 K/uL (normal range: 150-450 K/uL)
* Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL (normal range: 0.5-1.1 mg/dL)
* Lactic acid: 0.9 mmol/L (normal range: 0.5-2.0 mmol/L)

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Coronary artery disease
* Hypoxemic respiratory failure
* Metabolic alkalosis
* Fever
* Atrial fibrillation
* Pancreatitis
* Acute kidney injury
* Anemia
* Neurologic status: The patient is now very responsive and participatory, moves toes and arms well, turns head and tries to speak.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue plavix
* Continue aspirin
* Continue statin
* Continue low-dose beta blocker with pressor on for blood pressure support
* Hold lasix today
* Give one dose acetazolamide in addition in setting of metabolic alkalosis
* Trach stitches can be removed on [**1-19**]
* Continue to monitor post-Cath; risk of contrast-induced nephropathy starting up to 48 hours later
* Replete lytes PRN
* Continue to follow her clinical exam
* Continue tube feeds

Potential medical complications that can arise:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure can worsen if not managed properly.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation can lead to cardiac arrest if not managed properly.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury can worsen if not managed properly.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia can worsen if not managed properly.
* Neurologic complications: The patient's neurologic status can worsen if not managed properly.
* Infection: The patient's fever can indicate an underlying infection that needs to be managed properly.
* Contrast-induced nephropathy: The patient's exposure to contrast dye during cardiac catheterization can lead to contrast-induced nephropathy if not managed properly.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of her medical conditions to prevent potential complications.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory support is still required, and the risk of further respiratory distress is high due to the patient's underlying conditions, including acute congestive heart failure, pulmonary edema, and hypoxemic respiratory failure.
2. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient's pH is trending upwards, and further diuresis with lasix may exacerbate the condition. The patient's potassium levels are also low, which may require repletion.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is still elevated, and the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy is high due to the recent cardiac catheterization. Close monitoring of the patient's renal function is necessary.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely related to the tandem heart and recent bleeding. Transfusion as needed and monitoring of the patient's hematocrit are necessary.
5. Neurologic status: The patient's neurologic status is improving, but close monitoring is still necessary to ensure that there are no further complications.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia is likely related to the study protocol and may require further management.
7. Fever: The patient's fever is likely related to a distributive shock, and further evaluation is necessary to determine the source of the fever.
8. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation, may require further management and monitoring.
9. Pancreatitis: Although the patient's lipase levels are now normal, the risk of further pancreatitis is still present, and close monitoring is necessary.
10. Epistaxis: The patient's epistaxis is likely related to the recent bleeding and may require further management.

The patient's goals of care are to continue full code status and to be transferred to the CCU for further management. The patient's ICU care plan includes ongoing respiratory support, glycemic control, and monitoring of the patient's renal and hematological function.

   tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to partially in the RA
   causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. Removal of ECMO and tandem heart.
   Weaned pressors now only on phenylephrine. Improved mental status.
   Trach placed. Now s/p PCI with stent to left main, jailed LAD with
   balloon espansion with good flow.
   #. Coronary Artery Disease:
   Patient is s/p STEMI and cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest.   s/p PCI
   [**1-17**] of LMCA.
   - continue plavix, aspirin, statin
   - continue low dose beta blocker
   - will need anticoagulation b/c of apical hypokinesis but holding
   heparin gtt in setting of hct drop
   #. Hypoxemic respiratory failure:
   Likely secondary to pulmonary edema secondary to acute congestive heart
   failure, although hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, ARDS also on
   differential.
   - one time IV dose lasix this morning and monitor I/Os
   - trach stitches can be removed now
   #. Fever:
   Patient appeared to respond well to meropenem but has received full
   course antibiotics and is now not receiving any Abx.  Unclear what
   source of distributive shock is, may not be infectious.  AM cortisol
   within normal limits.  WBC stable.  Spiked another temperature this
   AM.  Pan-CT scan with no other source of infection.  C diff negative
   again yesterday.  Cultures negative except for pan-sensitive Klebsiella
   sputum which was thoguht to be colonization.  Central line resited
   yesterday. No concern on CT for pseudocyst or abscess in setting of
   recent pancreatitis.  beta glucan and galactomannan negative.
   - f/u final CT read
   - resend C diff today
   - pan culture when spikes again
   #. Anemia:
   CT torso without evidence of intraabdominal bleed.  Has had guaiac +
   stools. Tandem heart, which appeared associated with anemia, has been
   removed.  Transfused 2 units of pRBCs yesterday w lasix in between.
   Bronch clean.
   -          Pm hematocrit
   - hold heparin gtt
   #. Atrial fibrillation:
   Has been recurrent and intermittent.  Had no further episodes over
   atrial fibrillation overnight.  Has been Amiodarone IV loaded in the
   past.
   - cont telemetry
   - continue low dose beta blocker
   - holding heparin drip in setting of hct drop
   #Acute Kidney injury:
   Patient
s creatinine is now at 1.0 trending down from peak of 2.
   Presented w Cr 1.0 on admission. Making good urine to PO or IV lasix.
   Received mucomyst x5 doses prior to Cath.
   - replete lytes PRN
   - continue to monitor post Cath ; risk of contrast-induced nephropathy
   risk up to 48 hours later
   #. Neurologic status:
   Patient is now very responsive and participatory, moves toes and arms
   well, turns head and tries to speak.  CT head shows no evidence of
   stroke.
   - will continue to follow her clinical exam.
   # Nutrition:
   - continue tube feeds.
   - family discussion regarding placing PEG tube temporarily to help with
   LTAC placement and preventing sinus injury/infection
   # Hyperglycemia:
   No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] have been on hydrocortisone w

   over past several days.

Summary:

The patient, a 76-year-old woman, is a post-cardiac arrest patient with a history of STEMI and cardiogenic shock. She was transferred to the ICU after presenting with a left main occlusion and was treated with balloon angioplasty and stenting. She has been experiencing fevers of uncertain origin, with a Tmax over 101.5°F. Her physical examination reveals a right upper sternal systolic murmur, diffuse soft rhonchi, and mild distension of the abdomen. Laboratory results show anemia, acute kidney injury, and hyperglycemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Infectious complications: The patient's fevers of uncertain origin may indicate an underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis and multi-organ failure.
2. Bleeding complications: The patient's blood loss and low HCT may indicate ongoing bleeding, which could worsen her anemia and lead to further complications.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure may worsen if not managed properly, leading to respiratory arrest and death.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac history and ongoing atrial fibrillation may lead to further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
5. Nutritional complications: The patient's poor oral intake and need for tube feeds may lead to malnutrition and further compromise her immune function.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status is improving, but she may still be at risk for further neurological deterioration if not properly monitored and managed.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's guaiac-positive stools and frequent stools may indicate gastrointestinal bleeding or obstruction, which could worsen her anemia and lead to further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's temperature and blood pressure to detect any signs of infection or bleeding.
2. Consider ordering additional laboratory tests, such as blood cultures and a complete blood count, to help identify the source of the patient's fevers.
3. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure with ventilatory support and PEG tube placement.
4. Consider ordering an echocardiogram to assess the patient's cardiac function and identify any potential cardiac complications.
5. Monitor the patient's nutritional status and consider ordering a nutritional consult to ensure she is receiving adequate nutrition.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and consider ordering a neurological consult if her neurological symptoms worsen.
7. Consider ordering a gastrointestinal consult to evaluate the patient's gastrointestinal symptoms and identify any potential gastrointestinal complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 76-year-old female, is a post-cardiac arrest patient with a history of STEMI and cardiogenic shock. She has undergone PCI with stenting of the left main coronary artery and is currently receiving anticoagulation therapy with Plavix, aspirin, and statin. She is also receiving low-dose beta blocker therapy.

The patient's current condition is complicated by:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely secondary to pulmonary edema due to acute congestive heart failure.
2. Fever, which has persisted despite receiving full-course antibiotics. The source of the fever is unclear, and the patient's WBC count is stable.
3. Anemia, which is attributed to the tandem heart, which has been removed. The patient has received 2 units of packed red blood cells and has had guaiac-positive stools.
4. Acute kidney injury, which is being managed with IV lasix and electrolyte repletion.
5. Neurological status, which has improved with the patient becoming more responsive and participatory.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 101.5°F (38.6°C)
* Heart rate: 111 bpm (sinus bradycardia)
* Blood pressure: 89/44 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 23 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%

The patient's laboratory results are:

* White blood cell count: 8.1-8.8 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 22.6-31.6%
* Platelet count: 91-362 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.0-1.3 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 36-38 mg/dL
* Glucose: 143-154 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies are:

* CT sinus: unchanged moderate paranasal sinus disease with bilateral partial ostiomeatal unit occlusion
* CT chest/abdomen/pelvis: improved bilateral consolidations, peripancreatic fluid collections stable, minimal intrahepatic biliary dilation

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue anticoagulation therapy with Plavix, aspirin, and statin
* Continue low-dose beta blocker therapy
* Hold heparin drip in setting of hct drop
* Monitor I/Os and adjust IV lasix as needed
* Follow up with final CT read
* Resend C. diff test today
* Pan-culture when spikes again
* Replete lytes PRN
* Continue to monitor post-Cath risk of contrast-induced nephropathy

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Further deterioration of respiratory status
* Development of sepsis or septic shock
* Progression of anemia
* Worsening of acute kidney injury
* Development of neurological complications such as stroke or seizures
* Further cardiovascular complications such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after experiencing a syncope episode and chest pain. She has a history of coronary artery disease and has undergone PCI with stenting of the left main coronary artery.

Current Condition:

* Temperature: 101.5°F (38.6°C)
* Blood pressure: 89/44 mmHg
* Heart rate: 111 bpm (Sinus Bradycardia)
* Respiratory rate: 23 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* WBC count: 8.1-8.8 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 10.2-12.1 g/dL
* Platelet count: 208-282 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.0-1.3 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 30-43 mg/dL

Medical Complications:

1. Fever: The patient's temperature has spiked to 101.5°F (38.6°C) despite being on antibiotics. The source of the fever is unclear, and cultures are pending.
2. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's creatinine level has increased to 1.0-1.3 mg/dL, indicating acute kidney injury. The patient has been receiving lasix and has been making good urine output.
3. Anemia: The patient has been experiencing anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 10.2-12.1 g/dL. The etiology of the anemia is unclear, but the patient has been transfused with blood products.
4. Neurologic Status: The patient's neurologic status has improved, with increased responsiveness and participation in her care.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient has been experiencing hyperglycemia, with blood glucose levels ranging from 143-154 mg/dL. The patient does not have a history of diabetes, but has been receiving hydrocortisone as part of a study protocol.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever and WBC count may indicate sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, with a respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 287.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease and has undergone PCI with stenting. She may be at risk for cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
4. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's guaiac-positive stools and hemoglobin drop may indicate gastrointestinal bleeding, which could lead to hypovolemic shock and organ dysfunction.

Plan:

1. Continue antibiotics and monitor for signs of sepsis.
2. Adjust lasix dose based on urine output and blood pressure.
3. Continue transfusions as needed to treat anemia.
4. Monitor blood glucose levels and adjust insulin dose as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's neurologic status and adjust care accordingly.
6. Consider further imaging studies, such as a CT scan or MRI, to evaluate for potential sources of infection or bleeding.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust care accordingly.
8. Consider adding medications to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding, such as proton pump inhibitors or sucralfate.

   76F with [**Hospital 11306**] [**Hospital 1605**] transferred from OSH after syncope episode and chest
   pain, cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. POBA LAD
   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated after patient presents self cooled and in coma. On [**1-2**] became
   bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT arrest. Received a
   tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to partially in the RA
   causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. Removal of ECMO and tandem heart.
   Weaned pressors now only on phenylephrine. Improved mental status.
   Trach placed. Now s/p PCI with stent to left main, jailed LAD with
   balloon espansion with good flow.
   #. Coronary Artery Disease:
   Patient is s/p STEMI and cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest.   s/p PCI
   [**1-17**] of LMCA.
   - continue plavix, aspirin, statin
   - continue low dose beta blocker
   - will need anticoagulation b/c of apical hypokinesis but holding
   heparin gtt in setting of hct drop
   #. Hypoxemic respiratory failure:
   Likely secondary to pulmonary edema secondary to acute congestive heart
   failure, although hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, ARDS also on
   differential.
   - monitor I/O goal negative
   - trach stitches can be removed now
   #. Fever:
   Patient appeared to respond well to meropenem but has received full
   course antibiotics and is now not receiving any Abx.  Unclear what
   source of distributive shock is, may not be infectious.  AM cortisol
   within normal limits.  WBC stable.  Spiked another temperature this
   AM.  Pan-CT scan with no other source of infection.  C diff negative
   again yesterday.  Cultures negative except for pan-sensitive Klebsiella
   sputum which was thoguht to be colonization.  Central line resited
   yesterday. No concern on CT for pseudocyst or abscess in setting of
   recent pancreatitis.  beta glucan and galactomannan negative.
   - f/u sensitivities
   - vanc level
   - pan culture when spikes again
   #. Anemia:
   CT torso without evidence of intraabdominal bleed.  Has had guaiac +
   stools. Tandem heart, which appeared associated with anemia, has been
   removed.  Transfused 2 units of pRBCs yesterday w lasix in between.
   Bronch clean.
   - Pm hematocrit
   - hold heparin gtt
   #. Atrial fibrillation:
   Has been recurrent and intermittent.  Had no further episodes over
   atrial fibrillation overnight.  Has been Amiodarone IV loaded in the
   past.
   - cont telemetry
   - continue low dose beta blocker
   - holding heparin drip in setting of hct drop
   #Acute Kidney injury:
   Patient
s creatinine is now at 1.0 trending down from peak of 2.
   Presented w Cr 1.0 on admission. Making good urine to PO or IV lasix.
   Received mucomyst x5 doses prior to Cath.
   - replete lytes PRN
   - continue to monitor post Cath ; risk of contrast-induced nephropathy
   risk up to 48 hours later
   #. Neurologic status:
   Patient is now very responsive and participatory, moves toes and arms
   well, turns head and tries to speak.  CT head shows no evidence of
   stroke.
   - will continue to follow her clinical exam.
   # Nutrition:
   - continue tube feeds.
   - NPO p MN
   - PEG tomorrow
   # Hyperglycemia:
   No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] have been on hydrocortisone w

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital after experiencing a syncope episode and chest pain. She underwent cardiac catheterization, which revealed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She received percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stenting and is currently on anticoagulation therapy. She is also experiencing hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely secondary to pulmonary edema, and has a history of atrial fibrillation. She has been treated with antibiotics for suspected sepsis, but the source of the infection remains unclear. She is also experiencing anemia, acute kidney injury, and hyperglycemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Cardiac arrhythmias, such as atrial fibrillation or ventricular tachycardia, due to underlying cardiac disease or electrolyte imbalances.
	* Cardiac failure, particularly in the setting of acute coronary syndrome and cardiogenic shock.
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* Pneumonia or other respiratory infections, particularly in the setting of immunosuppression or prolonged ICU stay.
	* Respiratory failure, particularly in the setting of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or pulmonary edema.
3. Infection-Related Complications:
	* Sepsis, particularly in the setting of suspected sepsis or bacteremia.
	* Infective endocarditis, particularly in the setting of cardiac catheterization or implantable devices.
4. Neurological Complications:
	* Stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA), particularly in the setting of atrial fibrillation or cardiac embolism.
	* Seizures or status epilepticus, particularly in the setting of electrolyte imbalances or medication toxicity.
5. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* Gastrointestinal bleeding, particularly in the setting of anticoagulation therapy or gastrointestinal disease.
	* Pancreatitis or other gastrointestinal complications, particularly in the setting of pancreatic injury or disease.
6. Hematological Complications:
	* Anemia, particularly in the setting of bleeding, hemolysis, or bone marrow suppression.
	* Thrombocytopenia, particularly in the setting of bleeding or platelet dysfunction.
7. Renal Complications:
	* Acute kidney injury, particularly in the setting of sepsis, cardiac failure, or nephrotoxic medications.
	* Chronic kidney disease, particularly in the setting of underlying renal disease or medication toxicity.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for a range of medical complications, particularly in the setting of cardiac disease, respiratory failure, and infection. Close monitoring and aggressive management of these complications are essential to prevent further deterioration and improve the patient's outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female who was transferred to the ICU from the operating room after a cardiac catheterization procedure. She presented with syncope and chest pain, and was found to have 95% left main coronary artery disease and 99% left anterior descending artery stenosis. She underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stenting, and was intubated for respiratory distress. She has been receiving dopamine for hemodynamic support and has been on a heparin drip.

The patient has been experiencing a range of complications, including:

* Hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely secondary to pulmonary edema and acute congestive heart failure
* Fever, which has been attributed to a possible infection, but has not been fully resolved
* Anemia, which has been treated with blood transfusions
* Atrial fibrillation, which has been intermittent and has been treated with Amiodarone
* Acute kidney injury, which has been treated with lasix and is being closely monitored
* Neurological status, which has improved significantly since the patient's initial presentation

The patient's current vital signs include:

* Temperature: 38.3°C (100.9°F)
* Heart rate: 107 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 97/64 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 97%

The patient's laboratory results include:

* White blood cell count: 8.8 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 9.7 g/dL
* Platelet count: 190 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 26 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies include:

* Chest X-ray: shows evidence of bilateral pulmonary infiltrates
* Computed tomography (CT) scan: shows no evidence of intraabdominal bleed or abscess

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Pneumonia
* Sepsis
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Renal failure
* Neurological deterioration

The patient's current plan of care includes:

* Continue PCI and stenting
* Monitor I/O goal negative
* Trach stitches can be removed now
* Continue low dose beta blocker
* Hold heparin drip in setting of hct drop
* Continue tube feeds
* Monitor for signs of infection
* Continue to follow clinical exam
* Continue to monitor for signs of neurological deterioration

   pain, cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. POBA LAD
   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated after patient presents self cooled and in coma. On [**1-2**] became
   bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT arrest. Received a
   tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to partially in the RA
   causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. Removal of ECMO and tandem heart.
   Weaned pressors now only on phenylephrine. Improved mental status.
   Trach placed. Now s/p PCI with stent to left main, jailed LAD with
   balloon espansion with good flow.
   #. Coronary Artery Disease:
   Patient is s/p STEMI and cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest.   s/p PCI
   [**1-17**] of LMCA.
   - continue plavix, aspirin, statin
   - continue low dose beta blocker
   - will need anticoagulation b/c of apical hypokinesis but holding
   heparin gtt in setting of hct drop
   #. Hypoxemic respiratory failure:
   Likely secondary to pulmonary edema secondary to acute congestive heart
   failure, although hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, ARDS also on
   differential.
   - monitor I/O goal negative
   - trach stitches can be removed now
   #. Fever:
   Patient appeared to respond well to meropenem but has received full
   course antibiotics and is now not receiving any Abx.  Unclear what
   source of distributive shock is, may not be infectious.  AM cortisol
   within normal limits.  WBC stable.  Spiked another temperature this
   AM.  Pan-CT scan with no other source of infection.  C diff negative
   again yesterday.  Cultures negative except for pan-sensitive Klebsiella
   sputum which was thoguht to be colonization.  Central line resited
   yesterday. No concern on CT for pseudocyst or abscess in setting of
   recent pancreatitis.  beta glucan and galactomannan negative.
   - f/u final CT read
   - resend C diff today
   - pan culture when spikes again
   #. Anemia:
   CT torso without evidence of intraabdominal bleed.  Has had guaiac +
   stools. Tandem heart, which appeared associated with anemia, has been
   removed.  Transfused 2 units of pRBCs yesterday w lasix in between.
   Bronch clean.
   - Pm hematocrit
   - hold heparin gtt
   #. Atrial fibrillation:
   Has been recurrent and intermittent.  Had no further episodes over
   atrial fibrillation overnight.  Has been Amiodarone IV loaded in the
   past.
   - cont telemetry
   - continue low dose beta blocker
   - holding heparin drip in setting of hct drop
   #Acute Kidney injury:

s creatinine is now at 1.0 trending down from peak of 2.

   Received mucomyst x5 doses prior to Cath.
   - replete lytes PRN
   - continue to monitor post Cath ; risk of contrast-induced nephropathy
   risk up to 48 hours later

   Patient is now very responsive and participatory, moves toes and arms
   well, turns head and tries to speak.  CT head shows no evidence of
   stroke.
   - will continue to follow her clinical exam.
   # Nutrition:
   - continue tube feeds.
   - family discussion regarding placing PEG tube temporarily to help with
   LTAC placement and preventing sinus injury/infection - family agrees
   # Hyperglycemia:

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital after experiencing a syncope episode and chest pain. She was found to have 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis on cardiac catheterization. She underwent PCI with stenting to the left main coronary artery and was intubated for respiratory distress. She was also treated for cardiogenic shock and was placed on ECMO. She has since been weaned off pressors and is now on phenylephrine. Her mental status has improved, and she has been placed on a tracheostomy.

The patient has several ongoing medical conditions, including coronary artery disease, hypoxemic respiratory failure, fever, anemia, atrial fibrillation, acute kidney injury, and hyperglycemia. She is being treated with various medications and therapies, including antibiotics, anticoagulation, and insulin.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Coronary artery disease: The patient's coronary artery disease may continue to progress, leading to further complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and myocardial infarction.
2. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further complications such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), respiratory failure, and death.
3. Fever: The patient's fever may continue to spike, leading to further complications such as sepsis, organ failure, and death.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to further complications such as heart failure, respiratory failure, and death.
5. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may continue to recur, leading to further complications such as stroke, heart failure, and death.
6. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen, leading to further complications such as chronic kidney disease, end-stage renal disease, and death.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may continue to worsen, leading to further complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis, hyperosmolar nonketotic coma, and death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's coronary artery disease and adjust treatment as necessary.
2. Continue to treat the patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure with oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation as necessary.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's fever and adjust treatment as necessary.
4. Continue to treat the patient's anemia with blood transfusions and iron therapy as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's atrial fibrillation and adjust treatment as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's acute kidney injury and adjust treatment as necessary.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's hyperglycemia and adjust treatment as necessary.

ICU Care:

1. Nutrition: The patient is receiving tube feeds and should continue to receive nutrition through this route.
2. Glycemic control: The patient is receiving insulin sliding scale and should continue to receive this treatment.
3. Lines: The patient has multiple lines, including an arterial line, and should continue to receive IV fluids and medications as necessary.
4. Prophylaxis: The patient is receiving prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP, and should continue to receive these treatments.
5. Communication: The patient's code status is full code, and the family should be aware of this.
6. Disposition: The patient should continue to be monitored in the ICU until further notice.

   Central line resited yesterday. No concern on CT for pseudocyst or
   abscess in setting of recent pancreatitis.  beta glucan and
   galactomannan negative.
   - d/c a-line (resite if needed)
   - f/u sensitivities
   - vanc likely can be d/c'ed as coag neg staph likely contaminate
   - pan culture when spikes again
   #. Coronary artery disease: Patient is s/p STEMI and cardiogenic shock
   after PEA arrest.   s/p PCI [**1-17**] of LMCA.
   - continue plavix, aspirin, statin
   - continue low dose beta blocker
   - restart heparin gtt for apical akinesis - watch hct
   #. Anemia: CT torso without evidence of intraabdominal bleed.  Has had
   guaiac + stools. Tandem heart, which appeared associated with anemia,
   has been removed.  Transfused 2 units of pRBCs yesterday w lasix in
   between.  Bronch clean.
   - Pm hematocrit
   - restart heparin gtt
   #. Atrial fibrillation: Has been recurrent and intermittent.  Had no
   further episodes over atrial fibrillation overnight.  Has been
   Amiodarone IV loaded in the past.
   - cont telemetry
   - continue low dose beta blocker
   - heparin gtt
   #Acute Kidney injury: Patient
s creatinine is now at 1.1 trending down
   from peak of 2.  Presented w Cr 1.0 on admission.
   - replete lytes PRN
   #. Neurologic status: Patient is now very responsive and participatory,
   moves toes and arms well, turns head and tries to speak.  CT head shows
   no evidence of stroke.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease, who was admitted to the hospital after a syncope episode and chest pain. She underwent a cardiac catheterization, which showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She was treated with percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and received a stent to the left main coronary artery. She was also intubated for respiratory distress and received dopamine for hemodynamic support.

The patient's current condition is:

* Hypoxemic respiratory failure: likely secondary to pulmonary edema secondary to acute congestive heart failure, although hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, and ARDS are also on the differential.
* Hypotension: requiring intermittent pressors, with a goal of minimizing phenylephrine use.
* Fever: patient responded well to meropenem, but has received a full course of antibiotics and is no longer receiving any antibiotics. Unclear what source of distributive shock is, may not be infectious.
* Coronary artery disease: patient is s/p STEMI and cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest, with s/p PCI of LMCA.
* Anemia: patient had a hematocrit of 22.6% on admission, which has trended down to 30.2%. She has received 2 units of packed red blood cells and is being transfused with lasix.
* Atrial fibrillation: patient has had recurrent and intermittent episodes, with no further episodes overnight. She has been treated with Amiodarone IV loaded in the past.
* Acute kidney injury: patient's creatinine is now at 1.1, trending down from a peak of 2.0.
* Neurologic status: patient is now very responsive and participatory, with a normal CT head.
* Hyperglycemia: patient presented with hyperglycemia, with a peak glucose level of 190. She is being treated with regular insulin sliding scale.
* Insomnia: patient slept well last night and is being treated with Ambien.

Potential medical complications:

* Hypoxemic respiratory failure may lead to further respiratory distress and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Hypotension may lead to further hemodynamic instability and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Fever may lead to further distributive shock and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Coronary artery disease may lead to further cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrest or cardiogenic shock.
* Anemia may lead to further respiratory and cardiac complications.
* Atrial fibrillation may lead to further cardiac complications, such as stroke or cardiogenic shock.
* Acute kidney injury may lead to further kidney damage and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Hyperglycemia may lead to further complications, such as diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome.
* Insomnia may lead to further complications, such as sleep deprivation and potentially life-threatening consequences.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, it is recommended that she continue to receive close monitoring and treatment in the ICU.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of [**Hospital 11306**] [**Hospital 1605**] who was transferred to the ICU after a syncope episode and chest pain. She underwent cardiac catheterization, which revealed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She was treated with POBA LAD and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in the cath lab, intubated for respiratory distress, and received dopamine for hemodynamic support. She was also treated with hypothermia protocol and received a tandemheart, which was later removed. She was weaned off pressors and is currently on phenylephrine.

The patient has several ongoing medical issues, including:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: likely secondary to pulmonary edema secondary to acute congestive heart failure, although hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, and ARDS are also on the differential.
2. Hypotension: requiring intermittent pressors, which were weaned off overnight while sleeping.
3. Fever: patient has received full course of antibiotics and is now not receiving any antibiotics, with unclear source of distributive shock.
4. Coronary artery disease: patient is s/p STEMI and cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest, s/p PCI of LMCA.
5. Anemia: patient has had guaiac + stools, and tandem heart was removed.
6. Atrial fibrillation: patient has had recurrent and intermittent episodes, with no further episodes overnight.
7. Acute kidney injury: patient's creatinine is trending down from a peak of 2.
8. Neurologic status: patient is now very responsive and participatory, with no evidence of stroke on CT head.
9. Hyperglycemia: patient presented hyperglycemic and has been on hydrocortisone with study protocol, which has been stopped.
10. Insomnia: patient slept well last night.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure may worsen if not managed properly.
2. Cardiac complications: patient's coronary artery disease and cardiogenic shock may lead to further cardiac complications.
3. Infection: patient's fever and distributive shock may indicate an underlying infection, which needs to be further evaluated.
4. Anemia: patient's anemia may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications.
5. Neurologic complications: patient's altered mental status may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications.
6. Kidney injury: patient's acute kidney injury may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications.
7. Hyperglycemia: patient's hyperglycemia may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor patient's respiratory status and manage hypoxemic respiratory failure.
2. Continue to manage patient's hypotension with intermittent pressors.
3. Further evaluate patient's fever and distributive shock to determine underlying cause.
4. Continue to manage patient's coronary artery disease and cardiogenic shock.
5. Monitor patient's anemia and consider transfusions as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor patient's neurologic status and manage any further complications.
7. Monitor patient's kidney function and manage any further complications.
8. Manage patient's hyperglycemia and consider insulin therapy as necessary.
9. Continue to monitor patient's insulin levels and adjust therapy as necessary.
10. Consider restarting hydrocortisone therapy if patient's hyperglycemia persists.

   76F with [**Hospital 11306**] [**Hospital 1605**] transferred from OSH after syncope episode and chest
   pain, cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. POBA LAD
   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated after patient presents self cooled and in coma. On [**1-2**] became
   bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT arrest. Received a
   tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to partially in the RA
   causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. Removal of ECMO and tandem heart.
   Weaned pressors now only on phenylephrine. Improved mental status.
   Trach placed. Now s/p PCI with stent to left main, jailed LAD with
   balloon expansion with good flow.
   #. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: Likely secondary to pulmonary edema
   secondary to acute congestive heart failure, although hemorrhage,
   aspiration pneumonia, ARDS also on differential.
   - monitor I/O goal negative
   - continue to diurese with lasix gtt - goal net out 1L
   - trach stitches can be removed - will be done by csurg at time of PEG
   placement
   #. Hypotension: Requiring intermittent pressors. Was on phenylephrine
   overnight while sleeping for MAPs in 50s. While awake no pressor
   support required.
   - phenylephrine prn - try to minimize
   #. Fever: Patient appeared to respond well to meropenem but has
   received full course antibiotics and is now not receiving any Abx.
   Unclear what source of distributive shock is, may not be infectious.
   AM cortisol within normal limits.  WBC stable.  Spiked another
   temperature this AM.  Pan-CT scan with no other source of infection.  C
   diff negative again yesterday.  Cultures negative except for
   pan-sensitive Klebsiella sputum which was thoguht to be colonization.
   Central line resited yesterday. No concern on CT for pseudocyst or
   abscess in setting of recent pancreatitis.  beta glucan and
   galactomannan negative.
   - d/c a-line (resite if needed)
   - resite triple lumen (likely need cental venous access for now -
   hopefully will be able to do picc at some point if needed)
   - f/u sensitivities
   - vanc likely can be d/c'ed as coag neg staph likely contaminate
   - pan culture when spikes again
   #. Coronary artery disease: Patient is s/p STEMI and cardiogenic shock
   after PEA arrest.   s/p PCI [**1-17**] of LMCA.
   - continue plavix, aspirin, statin
   - continue low dose beta blocker
   - restart heparin gtt for apical akinesis - watch hct
   #. Anemia: CT torso without evidence of intraabdominal bleed.  Has had
   guaiac + stools. Tandem heart, which appeared associated with anemia,
   has been removed.  Transfused 2 units of pRBCs yesterday w lasix in
   between.  Bronch clean.
   - Pm hematocrit
   - restart heparin gtt
   #. Atrial fibrillation: Has been recurrent and intermittent.  Had no
   further episodes over atrial fibrillation overnight.  Has been
   Amiodarone IV loaded in the past.
   - cont telemetry
   - continue low dose beta blocker
   - heparin gtt
   #Acute Kidney injury: Patient
s creatinine is now at 1.1 trending down
   from peak of 2.  Presented w Cr 1.0 on admission.
   - replete lytes PRN
   #. Neurologic status: Patient is now very responsive and participatory,
   moves toes and arms well, turns head and tries to speak.  CT head shows
   no evidence of stroke.
   - will continue to follow her clinical exam.
   # Nutrition:
   - continue tube feeds.
   - PEG on Wed
   # Hyperglycemia: No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] have been on
   hydrocortisone w study protocol however, that medication stopped.
   - ISS - adjust prn
   # Insomnia: Slept well last night.
   - ambien
   # Goals of care
 patient now back to full code.

Summary:

The patient, a 76-year-old female, was admitted to the ICU after experiencing a syncope episode and chest pain. She underwent cardiac catheterization, which revealed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She was treated with POBA LAD and LCx with VT, intubated for respiratory distress, and received dopamine for hemodynamic support. She was also placed on ECMO, which was later removed. The patient has been weaned off pressors and is currently receiving phenylephrine. She has improved mental status and has been placed on a tracheostomy tube.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with a possible diagnosis of acute congestive heart failure, pulmonary edema, or aspiration pneumonia. Close monitoring of I/O goals and continued diuresis with lasix are necessary.
2. Hypotension: The patient requires intermittent pressors, and her blood pressure is being closely monitored. The goal is to minimize the use of phenylephrine.
3. Fever: The patient has had multiple temperatures, and it is unclear what is causing the distributive shock. Further evaluation, including pan-CT scans and cultures, is necessary to determine the source of infection.
4. Coronary artery disease: The patient has a history of STEMI and cardiogenic shock, and she has undergone PCI of the LMCA. She is being treated with plavix, aspirin, and statin, and her beta blocker dose is being adjusted.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is concerning, and further evaluation is necessary to determine the cause. She has received 2 units of PRBCs and has been restarted on heparin gtt.
6. Atrial fibrillation: The patient has had recurrent and intermittent atrial fibrillation, and her condition is being closely monitored.
7. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine is trending down, and her lytes are being repleted as needed.
8. Neurologic status: The patient's neurologic status is improving, and she is now very responsive and participatory.
9. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels are being closely monitored, and adjustments are being made to her insulin sliding scale as needed.
10. Insomnia: The patient slept well last night, and ambien is being considered for future use.

Labs and Radiology:

* WBC: 8.4-10.7
* Hct: 22.6-32.5
* Plt: 91.7-4.4
* Cr: 1.0-1.1
* TCO2: 32-27
* Glucose: 151-141
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T, ALT/AST, Alk Phos/T Bili, Amylase/Lipase, Differential-Neuts, Lactic Acid, Albumin, LDH, Ca++, Mg++, PO4

ICU Care:

* Nutrition: The patient is receiving tube feeds and will undergo PEG placement on Wednesday.
* Lines: The patient has an arterial line, a multi-lumen line, and a prophylactic heparin gtt.
* Prophylaxis: The patient is receiving prophylactic anticoagulation with heparin gtt, stress ulcer prophylaxis with an H2 blocker, and VAP prophylaxis.
* Code status: The patient is currently back to full code.

   Assessment and Plan
   76F with [**Hospital 11306**] [**Hospital 1605**] transferred from OSH after syncope episode and chest
   pain, cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. POBA LAD
   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated after patient presents self cooled and in coma. On [**1-2**] became
   bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT arrest. Received a
   tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to partially in the RA
   causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. Removal of ECMO and tandem heart.
   Continues to have pressor requirement. Improved mental status. Trach
   placed. Now s/p PCI with stent to left main, jailed LAD with balloon
   expansion with good flow.
   #. Hypotension: Requiring pressors. Particularly while sleeping. Able
   to wean off phenylephrine at times, however, when sleeping has
   increased requirement. Started midodrine and able to partially wean
   phenylephrine.
   - continue to wean phenylephrine
   - decrease beta blocker now that amiodarone on board
   - attempt I/O even for the day, patient may be dry
   #. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: Likely secondary to pulmonary edema
   secondary to acute congestive heart failure, although hemorrhage,
   aspiration pneumonia, ARDS also on differential.
   - monitor I/O goal - even
   - continue lasix gtt
   - trach stitches can be removed - will be done by CT Surgery at time of
   PEG placement
   - wean vent settings
   - trial of pressure support
   #. Fever: Patient appeared to respond well to meropenem but has
   received full course antibiotics and is now not receiving any Abx.
   Unclear what source of distributive shock is, may not be infectious.
   AM cortisol within normal limits.  WBC stable.  Fevers yesterday.
   Pan-CT scan with no other source of infection.  C diff negative
   multiple times.  Cultures negative except for pan-sensitive Klebsiella
   sputum which was thought to be colonization, persistent despite all
   antibiotic treatment.  Central line resited, A-line DCed. 1 bottle
   positive for Coag Neg Staph, likely contaminant.  No concern on CT for
   pseudocyst or abscess in setting of recent pancreatitis.  beta glucan
   and galactomannan negative.
   - f/u cultures
   - trend WBC, T
   #. Coronary artery disease:  Patient is s/p STEMI and cardiogenic shock
   after PEA arrest.  s/p PCI [**1-17**] of LMCA.
   - continue plavix, aspirin, statin
   - decrease beta blocker
   - continue heparin gtt for apical akinesis - watch hct
   #. Anemia: CT torso without evidence of intraabdominal bleed.  Has had
   guaiac + stools. Tandem heart, which appeared associated with anemia,
   has been removed.  Bronch clean.  On heparin drip. Hct stable.
   - will monitor Hct daily
   - transfuse if evidence of hypoperfusion
   #. Atrial fibrillation: Has been recurrent and intermittent.  Had
   another episode of atrial fibrillation overnight.
   - continue amiodarone po
   - consider beta blocker withdrawal
   - continue heparin gtt
   #Acute Kidney injury: Patient
s creatinine is now at 1.8. Trending up
   from 1.1.  Presented w Cr 1.0 on admission. Worrisome for pre-renal
   picture.
   - replete lytes PRN
   - urine lytes
   - trend BUN/Cr
   #. Neurologic status: Patient is now very responsive and participatory,
   moves toes and arms well, turns head and tries to speak.  CT head shows
   no evidence of stroke.
   - will continue to follow her clinical exam
    # Nutrition:
   - stopped tf for possible procedure -  will restart if not planning on
   PEG today
   - NPO p Midnight for PEG
   # Hyperglycemia: No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] have been on
   hydrocortisone w study protocol however, that medication stopped.
   - ISS - adjust prn
   # Insomnia/ Depression:   Ambien works well intermittently.  Patient
   needs rest to help w anxiety
   - continue ambien
   - continue citalopram
   # Goals of care
 FULL CODE

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of cardiac catheterization showing 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. She presented with syncope, chest pain, and was intubated for respiratory distress. She was treated with POBA LAD and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in the cath lab, and intubated for respiratory distress.

The patient has had multiple complications, including:

1. Hypotension: Requiring pressors, particularly while sleeping. She has been started on midodrine and able to partially wean phenylephrine.
2. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: Likely secondary to pulmonary edema secondary to acute congestive heart failure, although hemorrhage, aspiration pneumonia, and ARDS are also on the differential.
3. Fever: Patient appeared to respond well to meropenem but has received a full course of antibiotics and is now not receiving any antibiotics. Unclear what source of distributive shock is, may not be infectious.
4. Coronary artery disease: Patient is s/p STEMI and cardiogenic shock after PEA arrest. She has had a PCI of the LMCA.
5. Anemia: Patient has had guaiac + stools and has been on heparin drip. Hct is stable.
6. Atrial fibrillation: Patient has had recurrent and intermittent episodes of atrial fibrillation.
7. Acute kidney injury: Patient's creatinine is now at 1.8, trending up from 1.1. Presented with Cr 1.0 on admission, worrisome for pre-renal picture.
8. Neurologic status: Patient is now very responsive and participatory, moves toes and arms well, turns head and tries to speak. CT head shows no evidence of stroke.

The patient's current medications include:

* Amiodarone PO
* Midodrine 5mg TID
* Lasix gtt
* Heparin gtt
* Plavix
* Aspirin
* Statin
* Hydrocortisone (stopped)
* Citalopram
* Ambien

The patient's current labs include:

* WBC: 10.7
* Hct: 32.5
* Plt: 192
* Cr: 1.8
* TCO2: 31
* Glucose: 138
* Amylase: 26
* Lipase: 232
* LDH: 441 IU/L
* Ca++: 7.8 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.7 mg/dL
* PO4: 3.2 mg/dL

The patient's current imaging studies include:

* CXR: Showing bilateral basal opacities and increase in extent of the retrocardiac opacity, likely caused by a combination of pulmonary edema and infection.
* CT head: Showing no evidence of stroke.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Continue to wean phenylephrine
* Decrease beta blocker now that amiodarone is on board
* Attempt I/O even for the day, patient may be dry
* Continue lasix gtt
* Wean vent settings
* Trial of pressure support
* Follow-up cultures
* Trend WBC and T
* Continue plavix, aspirin, and statin
* Decrease beta blocker
* Continue heparin gtt for apical akinesis
* Monitor Hct daily and transfuse if evidence of hypoperfusion
* Continue amiodarone PO
* Consider beta blocker withdrawal
* Continue heparin gtt

The patient's current goals of care include:

* FULL CODE
* ICU care
* Nutrition: NPO p MN
* Glycemic control: Regular insulin sliding scale
* Lines: Multi-lumen
* Prophylaxis: DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

   76F with [**Hospital 11306**] [**Hospital 1605**] transferred from OSH after syncope episode and chest
   pain, cardiac cath showed 95% LM disease and 99% LAD stenosis. POBA LAD
   and LCx with VT s/p shock twice in cath lab, intubated for respiratory
   distress, dopamine for hemodynamic support. Hypothermia protocal was
   initiated after patient presents self cooled and in coma. On [**1-2**] became
   bradycardic, atropine was given, PEA to VT arrest. Received a
   tandemheart in cath lab, however retracted to partially in the RA
   causing a shunt. ECMO was initiated. Removal of ECMO and tandem heart.
   Continues to have pressor requirement. Improved mental status. Trach
   placed. Now s/p PCI with stent to left main, jailed LAD with balloon
   expansion with good flow.
   #. Hypotension: Requiring pressors. Particularly while sleeping. Able
   to wean off phenylephrine at times, however, when sleeping has
   increased requirement. Started midodrine and able to partially wean
   phenylephrine.
   - continue to wean phenylephrine
   - d/c beta blocker now that amiodarone on board
   - attempt I/O even for the day, patient may be dry
   #. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: Likely secondary to pulmonary edema
   secondary to acute congestive heart failure, although hemorrhage,
   aspiration pneumonia, ARDS also on differential.
   - monitor I/O goal - even
   - continue lasix gtt
   - trach stitches can be removed - will be done by CT Surgery at time of
   PEG placement
   - wean vent settings
   - trial of pressure support
   #. Fever: Patient appeared to respond well to meropenem but has
   received full course antibiotics and is now not receiving any Abx.
   Unclear what source of distributive shock is, may not be infectious.
   AM cortisol within normal limits.  WBC stable.  Fevers yesterday.
   Pan-CT scan with no other source of infection.  C diff negative
   multiple times.  Cultures negative except for pan-sensitive Klebsiella
   sputum which was thought to be colonization, persistent despite all
   antibiotic treatment.  Central line resited, A-line DCed. 1 bottle
   positive for Coag Neg Staph, likely contaminant.  No concern on CT for
   pseudocyst or abscess in setting of recent pancreatitis.  beta glucan
   and galactomannan negative.
   - f/u cultures
   - trend WBC, T
   #. Coronary artery disease:  Patient is s/p STEMI and cardiogenic shock
   after PEA arrest.  s/p PCI [**1-17**] of LMCA.
   - continue plavix, aspirin, statin
   - consider d/c beta blocker
   - continue heparin gtt for apical akinesis - watch hct
   #. Anemia: CT torso without evidence of intraabdominal bleed.  Has had
   guaiac + stools. Tandem heart, which appeared associated with anemia,
   has been removed.  Bronch clean.  On heparin drip. Hct stable.
   - will monitor Hct daily
   - transfuse if evidence of hypoperfusion
   #. Atrial fibrillation: Has been recurrent and intermittent.  Had
   another episode of atrial fibrillation overnight.
   - continue amiodarone po
   - consider beta blocker withdrawal
   - continue heparin gtt
   #Acute Kidney injury: Patient
s creatinine is now at 1.8. Trending up
   from 1.1.  Presented w Cr 1.0 on admission. Worrisome for pre-renal
   picture.
   - replete lytes PRN
   - urine lytes
   - trend BUN/Cr
   #. Neurologic status: Patient is now very responsive and participatory,
   moves toes and arms well, turns head and tries to speak.  CT head shows
   no evidence of stroke.
   - will continue to follow her clinical exam
    # Nutrition:
   - stopped tf for possible procedure -  will restart if not planning on
   PEG today
   - NPO p Midnight for PEG
   # Hyperglycemia: No h/o DM, presented hyperglycemic.  [**Month (only) 8**] have been on

   - ISS - adjust prn

   received full course antibiotics and is now not receiving any Abx.
   Unclear what source of distributive shock is, may not be infectious.
   AM cortisol within normal limits.  WBC stable.  Fevers yesterday.
   Pan-CT scan with no other source of infection.  C diff negative
   multiple times.  Cultures negative except for pan-sensitive Klebsiella
   sputum which was thought to be colonization, persistent despite all
   antibiotic treatment.  Central line resited, A-line DCed. 1 bottle
   positive for Coag Neg Staph, likely contaminant.  No concern on CT for
   pseudocyst or abscess in setting of recent pancreatitis.  beta glucan

s creatinine is now at 1.8. Trending up

   moves toes and arms well, turns head and tries to speak.  CT head shows
   no evidence of stroke.
   - will continue to follow her clinical exam
    # Nutrition:
   - stopped tf for possible procedure -  will restart if not planning on

   - NPO p Midnight for PEG

   - ISS - adjust prn
